bibl.title: Smith, Winchell. The fortune hunter : a comedy in four acts

castList.head: THE FORTUNE HUNTER.
CAST OF CHARACTERS.
castList.castItem: HENRY KELLOGG A rising young financier
JAMES LONG "JIM" A Wall Street young man
LAWRENCE MILLER "LARRY" A Wall Street young man

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE: — The sitting-room of HENRY KELLOGG'S bachelor apartment in East 31st St., near 5th Avenue, New York City . The set is very elaborate from a man's point of view. Medallion on the floor. Up R. mahogany couch with sofa pillows. Several mahogany chairs of various sizes about the room. Down L. C. is writing table with large blotting pad, writing paper, pens, pencils, ink stand and paper cutter, etc. Waste paper basket beside the table. Also large electric stand lamp on this table . ( Practical .) Up C. is alcove with open grate, with andirons, fire-hook, etc. Above the grate is mantel with several pieces of bric-a-brac. A window at R. and one at L. of alcove. Hat and coat rack at entrance up R. C. Book cases built into the walls filled with books . Up R. C. is door ( Entrance from street ) leading into a little alcove. Portierres in arch of this alcove. Down R. is door leading off to bedrooms . L. is doorway leading into dining-room and kitchen. Portierres in this doorway .
TIME: — June — 6:30 P. M.
[Figure: 109KB
DISCOVERED: — At rise of curtain , ROBBINS, who is KELLOGG'S valet, is crossing stage. He opens door up R. C. and takes several evening papers from a paper boy who stands outside in doorway .

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
I suppose that you know you're two hours' late with these to-night?
( boy looks at ROBBINS with expressionless face )
It's past six.
( another short pause )
There are plenty of other places about here where I can order papers and the next time you're late I'll find one.

sp.speaker: NEWSBOY.
sp.p: All right.

div.stage: (ROBBINS closes door sharply, comes grumbling to fire-place up C. and turns on lights, then down stage to table. He puts papers on table and after selecting one for himself, is about to read when the door bell rings. He makes a wry face, goes to the door, taking the paper with him. He holds the door open as GEORGE BURNHAM enters .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: How are you, Robbins?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Good-evening, Mr. Burnham.

div.stage: (BURNHAM comes down C.)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Mr. Kellogg here?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: He hasn't come in yet, sir, but it's time for him. Won't you sit down? He won't be long now.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Well, I've a train to catch at 7:18.
( sits right of table )
I'll leave a note for him and try to see him to-morrow.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Very good, sir.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Yes, I guess to-morrow will be better. Probably he won't want to talk business to-night, eh?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: How so, sir?

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
How so? Why haven't you been reading it there?
(BURNHAM points to newspaper ROBBINS still holds )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
You haven't? Why, you've got your thumb right on it.
(ROBBINS looks at paper quickly . BURNHAM watches ROBBINS' face, which shows great surprise )
What do you think of that?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.stage: ( after a glance at paper — ejaculating )
sp.p: Junior member of the firm!

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
That's what! From now on it won't be L. J. Bartlett but L. J. Bartlett &.mp; Co.
( begins to write )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: It's a great promotion, sir.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: To be taken into the biggest firm on Wall Street. I should say it was a great promotion, and Harry — I mean, Mr. Kellogg, deserves it too. Deserves every bit of it, you tell him I said so. Why, he's pulled off more deals for them in the last year.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: He's been very successful, sir.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
You can bet he has. He's a great business man and no mistake. If he lives he'll be one of our big millionaires, as sure as you're born. He can't help making money any more than I can, and no one is any more pleased over this big jump than me. You just tell him I said that, will you?
( resumes writing )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Very good, sir. I'll tell him.

div.stage: ( Door bell rings . ROBBINS starts to door . BURNHAM looks at watch .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Is that him?

div.stage: (ROBBINS stops .)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
No, sir. He always uses his key.
( turns up )

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Wait a minute.
(ROBBINS stops again )
I'm goin'.
( tears up paper )
Never mind this note.
(BURNHAM goes up to get his hat )
He 'phoned me to call, but he's late. Just say I was here, will you?
( at door )
He knows what it's about and you tell him that crude oil and gas proposition is sure fire and I'll see him to-morrow.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I'll tell him, sir.

div.stage: ( As ROBBINS opens door , JAMES LONG ( called JIM), carrying a parcel, and LAWRENCE MILLER ( called LARRY) stand in the doorway .)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: Ah, Robbins —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Excuse me, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: Certainly, certainly!

div.stage: ( Both men stand aside and BURNHAM exits . JIM comes down and continues .)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p:
Certainly, certainly. Is Mr. Kellogg in?
( crosses to R. of table )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I expect him every moment, Mr. Long.

div.stage: (LARRY hands ROBBINS his hat .)

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.stage: ( in surprise. Sits on arm of chair R. C.)
sp.p: Not home yet?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Not yet, sir.

div.stage: (ROBBINS takes JIM'S hat and crosses up to hat-rack .)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: No wonder he's late to-night. Have you heard the news, Robbins?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I've just seen it in the evening paper, sir.

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: Do you think Mr. Kellogg knew about it?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I don't think so, sir. I never heard him mention it.

div.stage: (JIM takes out knife, cuts string and opens package, disclosing two quart bottles of champagne . ROBBINS crossing L.)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p:
Mr. Miller and I came up to drink to the new partnership, Robbins. Have you got a cooler?
(JIM crosses R. C. to ROBBINS)
Don't want these to get warm!

div.stage: ( Door bell rings .)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I'll see to them, sir.

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: There he is.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: No sir. He wouldn't ring.

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.stage: ( still holding bottles. Starts for door L.)
sp.p:
Here, wait! You attend to the door ROBBINS. We'll do this. I know where the ice-box is in every house I go to. Come on,
( at door )
Larry.

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: Right you are.

div.stage: ( Exit JIM and LARRY L. ROBBINS goes up to door U. R. C. showing in NATHANIEL DUNCAN, called Nat. He has top coat thrown over his arm, carries stick and umbrella strapped on dress-suit case in the other hand. He comes into the room , ROBBINS regarding him with surprise .)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
Why, Mr. Duncan!
(NAT comes down into room )

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p:
Hello ROBBINS!
(ROBBINS takes coat and hat to rack and closes door )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I thought you were out West, sir?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: But it was only yesterday Mr. Kellogg sent you a letter to Omaha.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I didn't get that far —

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Didn't — didn't you like the business, sir?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
No, I don't like any business but that isn't the reason I didn't get to Omaha.
( crosses ROBBINS R.)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
No, sir?
( taking suit case )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looks at ROBBINS and says quietly )
sp.p: They fired me, Robbins —

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: I'm very sorry, sir!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( after a moment's grateful glance at ROBBINS.)
sp.p: Oh, it's all right. I'm used to it. Where's my trunk?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: In your room, sir.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I want to get some clean things out of it. Fetch along the suit case will you? I'll send for the trunk to-morrow.
( starts toward R. door )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.stage: ( down C. with suit case. Great surprise )
sp.p: Send for your trunk?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Yes, Robbins, send for my trunk and get it out of your way.
(NAT turns R.)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Are you going away, again sir? Have you got another position?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, no position, but I'm not going to hang out here any longer.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: May I ask, sir, where you're going to?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Hell, I think. Here let me have that.
( taking suit case )

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Mr. Kellogg will never allow you to leave here, sir.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: He'll have to.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
Oh, you are only just a bit blue, Mr. Duncan.
( indicating chair R. of table )
Come, come, please sit down and let me get you something.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, you get it while I pack.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: And Robbins —

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Yes, sir?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Only put a little in it.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Only a little what?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Seltzer!
( Exits R.)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
Yes, sir.
( exits L. laughing. A moment's pause )

div.stage: (HENRY KELLOGG, ( called HARRY,) opens the door U. R. C. with latch key , WILLIAM BARTLETT, ( called WILLIE) who is with him enters . KELLOGG follows BARTLETT in .)

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: I can't stop Kellogg really. I was dressing at the Club, happened to see it in the paper and just dropped around to congratulate you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Your father hadn't told you of it, then?

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: No, the Governor gave up talking business with me long ago. I can't get interested in it. Of course I knew he thought a lot of you and all that, but I hadn't a notion they were going to take you into the firm.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I hadn't the slightest idea of it myself until your father called me into his office this morning.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: Well, I'm jolly glad of it, old chap. I —

div.stage: (JIM and LARRY enter L. JIM with bottles of champagne opened and LARRY with tray of glasses .)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: All hail to the future King of American Finance!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Hello, boys, where the deuce did you come from?

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.stage: (L. of table. Putting glasses on table . JIM fills them )
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, we won't stay long. We only came around to take our hats off to you.

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: And tell you what a great fellow we think you are.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Oh — that's it. Do you know, Mr. Barlett? Mr. Miller, Mr. Long.

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: Glad to know you, Mr. Bartlett.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: How de do.

div.stage: ( As WILLIE turns to LARRY.)

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: I know Mr. Bartlett.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: Oh yes, how are you, Miller? Glad to see you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Mr. Bartlett is the son of my employer.

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: Your what?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I mean the son of my partner.

div.stage: ( Goes up R. to hat-rack and arranges his tie .)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: That's better!

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: So you've taken him into the firm?

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: The Governor has. I'm not in the business, you know — Not the slightest turn for it!

div.stage: (HARRY returns C.)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.stage: ( goes above table to WILLIE, with the filled glasses )
sp.p:
Here we are.
( hands glasses to WILLIE and LARRY. HARRY R. C.)
We'll drink to him first and then
( goes to HARRY and gives him a glass )
he can drink to his royal little self.
( returns above table, raising glass )
Here's to Henry Kellogg of the firm of L. J. Bartlett &.mp; Company.

div.stage: ( Enter NAT R., dress-suit case in one hand. Sees others .)

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: Hear, hear!

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: Good work.

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p:
To the boy who is getting on in the world.
( sees NAT. No one shows surprise at NAT'S presence except HARRY)
Ah, Nat, just in time.

div.stage: (NAT goes to meet HARRY and JIM comes down around table with glass — gets another glass and fills it .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( crosses quickly and grasping NAT'S hand )
sp.p:
Why, hello, Nat, when did you strike town?
(ROBBINS enters and goes above table )
All my friends seem to be here to-night.
( turns )
Gad, it's a regular surprise party.
( goes C. ROBBINS, with glass on tray, crossing above the others to NAT)
Are there any more around here, Robbins?

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: No, sir, Mr. Burnham called, sir, but he wouldn't wait.

div.stage: (ROBBINS and JIM reach NAT at the same time, each offer a glass . NAT looks from one to the other, then puts down the suit case and takes both glasses, they all laugh .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Burnham? Oh, yes, I promised to meet him here.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
He'll see you to-morrow.
( crosses to HARRY, then stops and turns )
Excuse me, sir, but he thinks you deserve all your success and he wants you to know he said so.
( there is a slight laugh. Exits L.)

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p:
Well, already now.
( lifts his glass L. of table )
Come on, Nat!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What's it all about?

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: Why, Harry's good fortune, of course.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What good fortune?

div.stage: ( The men look at him .)

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: You don't mean to say you haven't heard?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Heard what?

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: Why, that Bartlett has made Harry a partner!

div.stage: (NAT looks quickly at HARRY.)

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: That's what we're here for — to congratulate him.

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: Now do you understand? Once more now. To the boy that's getting on in the world!

div.stage: ( They drink . NAT drinks from glass , ROBBINS has brought him. Eyes still on HARRY.)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am blushing.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, Gee, I'm awful glad, old man!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Why, of course you are. You got back rather suddenly, didn't you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: I say, Duncan, don't you remember me?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Willie Bartlett!

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p:
I haven't seen you for years. Not since you left college.
( to the others )
Whenever I used to go on a spree I'd always get Duncan to show me around.

div.stage: (HARRY goes L.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, I was pretty good at that!

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p:
By Jove, he knew more pretty girls!
( to NAT)
Do you know as many now?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, the list has shrunk.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: Oh, I don't believe it. Remember the night you took me out and showed me how to play Faro Bank?

div.stage: (HARRY, JIM and LARRY talk at L. of table .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Yes, I remember. And I remember what a yap we thought my room-mate was, because he wouldn't come with us.
( indicating HARRY)
He was my room-mate.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: What, Kellogg?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Ah, ha!
( takes suit case, starts for door )
Good-night, Harry. See you later, boys.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Over to the hotel.

div.stage: (JIM goes up L. LARRY to table .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Hotel? What hotel?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Where I'm stopping.

div.stage: (ROBBINS enters, goes to hat-rack above table. Gets hats, etc. )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Where you're — well, here,
you can't go just yet. I haven't had a chance to talk to you.

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p: Well, we'll toddle along.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( turns to JIM and LARRY, then talks )
sp.p: Oh, don't hurry. We've just got here.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p:
I must go, anyway, I've a dinner engagement.
( starts toward door )

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p: You'll be late, won't you?

div.stage: (WILLIE stops, goes to HARRY.)

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p:
Doesn't matter. I'm always late. Good-night, Kellogg. Congratulations again.
( turns R. to NAT)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Must you go, really?

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.stage: ( to NAT, producing card case and taking out card )
sp.p:
Look me up, will you, Duncan? We must have a regular old-fashioned night of it sometime, just for memory's sake.
( gives NAT card )

div.stage: (HARRY and JIM go to door .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: (R. C. taking card, puts suit case down )
sp.p: I've memories enough, thanks.

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p:
Well, for any reason at all, so long as we have the night.
( goes up )

div.stage: ( During this JIM and LARRY have been saying "Good-night" to HARRY. HARRY urging them to stay longer — all in pantomime . LARRY comes down R. — shakes NAT'S hand, saying: )

sp.speaker: LARRY.
sp.p:
So long Nat.
( Nearly together )

sp.speaker: JIM.
sp.p:
Good-night, old man.
( Nearly together )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Good-night.

div.stage: (ROBBINS has brought their hats and JIM and LARRY, and WILLIE exit . ROBBINS holding the door for them .)

sp.speaker: WILLIE.
sp.p: Which way do you chaps go? I've got my car —

div.stage: ( The door closes .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I haven't dined yet, have you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, but —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Good! Suppose we dine here, together.
( as NAT is about to object )
Robbins!

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Order dinner for Mr. Duncan and me from the Club.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Hurry it up, Robbins, we're hungry.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
Yes, sir.
( starts R., then remembering, turns at door L.)
Oh, Mr. Burnham left a message. Said that crude oil and gas proposition was sure fire and he'd see you about it to-morrow. Oh, pardon me, sir, but will you allow me to offer my congratulations?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Of course, I will, Robbins, thank you.

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
I'm very glad, sir.
(ROBBINS exits L.)

div.stage: (HARRY is so excited and happy he can think of nothing but his own good luck. Goes to NAT, and putting his hand on NAT'S shoulders .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, I'm feeling pretty good to-night, Nat.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
You ought to be.
( turns away and sits R. of table L. C.)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You could have knocked me down with a feather when they sprung it on me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: When did they tell you?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Only this morning. I thought they might boost my salary for they knew other people on the street had made me offers, but a partnership with L. J. BARTLETT. Think of it!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I've been thinking of it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: It will keep me mighty busy, but you know I like to work.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
That's right — you do.
( with a half sigh )
It must be a great thing to like to work.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
You bet it's a great thing. Why, I shouldn't care to live if I couldn't work.
( sits on edge of table L. C.)
Remember the time I went into the country for my health?
(NAT nods "yes" )
I'll never forget it. Hanging around all the time, doing nothing and every one else busy. Why, I wouldn't go through it again for a fortune. I felt so useless and in the way —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: But, you could pay your board — You had money?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Of course, but I felt in the way, just the same.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You did?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I did, indeed.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Suppose you didn't have any money and couldn't pay your board. How would you feel then?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( seeing what NAT is driving at and quickly changing the subject )
sp.p: Oh, nonsense. But, what are you doing East? I didn't expect you back for two months. I've been so busy talking about myself —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Go on talking.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: No. Tell me why you came home?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: My firm did what yours did — sent for me —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Wire came two days ago.
( takes up highball glass )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I got in this afternoon.
( short pause )
I didn't exactly think they'd boost my salary — and they didn't —
( shakes glass to cool drink )
You see they
did'nt know that other people made me any offers.
( looks up at HARRY)
And they had'nt?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Have you seen them yet?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, I've seen 'em!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Who'd you see?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Spaulding.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Said he wanted to ask my advice.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: About what?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Whether I thought it was best for them to give up their customers in my territory or send a man out there who could sell goods —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( laughing and getting off table, stands with back to front )
sp.p: Did Spaulding say that?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Something like that —
( slight pause )
Oh, he was all right. Offered me a month's salary. Guess he thought it was worth that to get rid of me.
( drinks )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( after a little pause, in a half scolding tone )
sp.p: Oh, well, don't let it knock you out? That month's salary will last a while.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I didn't take it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You didn't?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I might have known I couldn't make good. The thing I mind most is — is that it was you who got the job for me —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Don't think of that for a moment. I'll find you something else before long and —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No you won't.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Don't talk that way. I'll get you in right somewhere only —
( sudden thought )
By Jove — the very thing? Here's this chap Burnham promoting a wonderful scheme for making gas from crude oil. He needs my help! I'll get you in there.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What good would I be? What do I know about crude oil and gas?

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: But you can learn. All you need —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Wait a minute Harry. Now once and for all I'm through having you recommend an incompetent man just because we're friends and I'm through living on you when I'm out of a job.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You ought to know that you're perfectly welcome.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I know all that and more.
( looks HARRY in the eye )
I know you've been a prince to me; I know you've kept me going for two years, ever since I found out I couldn't make a living for myself, and I know I can't stand for your doing it any longer.
( they look at each other )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, then that's settled.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, that's settled!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Do you mind telling me what you're going to do?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( turning, after waiting for NAT to continue )
sp.p: What do you mean by "No?"

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I mean I don't mind telling you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, what is it then?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Oh!
( there is a pause. Sitting L. of table )
Nat, I've known you for nine years.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Is it that long?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, sir, nine years. And you can't room with a fellow all through college without knowing him pretty well. I know everything about you as well as you know it yourself and I tell you you were brought up all wrong.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, I've been brought down all right.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You know your father always sent you more cash than you could spend and never let you think of the value of money, or how hard it is to earn, and then —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, and then he went broke — and died.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes; and all you had left was an impractical education in your head.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: And not enough of that so you'd notice it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: No wonder you couldn't jump in and earn money.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That's all very fine but the truth of it is, I haven't got it in me. I hate work as much as you like it, but at that I had a good hard try. You may not think so, but I did; and I found out that they don't pay enough for any work that I can do for a man to live decently on.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What do you mean by decently?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Have you ever tried living in a six dollar a week New York boarding-house?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I have. Kept books in a fish market for nine. Tried paying laundry bills and clothing myself on three. Did the whole thing; you know, only one schooner of beer a day and rolled my own cigarettes. Didn't have to get to work until five in the morning and I lasted eight weeks at that job, before I was taken sick. Shows what a great constitution I have. I've tried all the jobs that are open to a man with a knowledge of Latin and Greek and higher mathematics. Shipping clerk, time-keeper, cashier, all of 'em; and I decided that I'd rather die than live the way I had to live on such wages. I thought I had a chance when I was taken ill at the fish market — there was nothing doing; I was well again in two weeks. Perhaps a fellow can stand those boarding-houses that's been brought up in them — but when you've been used to the other thing, it's unbearable — filthy rooms — awful grub and the crowd you have to meet.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: And that's what you are thinking of going back to?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I will, before I'll sponge on you any longer. But on the level I'd rather try the East River or turn
the gas on. What's the use? That's the way I feel.
( looks front )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Oh, rot! All you want is a way to earn some money.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, get it! I'll never be able to earn it! That's a cinch!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well! There are ways to " get " it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I wish I understood the burglar business.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Would you steal to get it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I can't think of anything I wouldn't do to get it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I know a way, if you're not too particular that you can be worth a million in a year.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( about to light a cigarette, stops. Looks at HARRY)
sp.p: Say that again.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You can be worth a million dollars in one year.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( still looks at him and then smiles )
sp.p: What would they do with me if I were caught?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Oh, it's perfectly legal. Done every day.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: And I could do it?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
A fellow like you couldn't fail.
(NAT after a moment's pause, takes up and drinks rest of drink )
Why, I've thought this scheme over for years and I'll bet anything it'll work. Would you like to try it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Would I like to try it?
( short laugh )
That's my first laugh this month.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'll tell you how you can do it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, don't kid me, Harry.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Never more serious in my life. If you want to try it, and will follow the rules I give you I'll guarantee you'll be a millionaire in a year.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( seeing HARRY is in earnest, speaks very rapidly with excitement )
sp.p: I'll follow all the rules in the world. Come on! I'm getting palpitation of the heart. What have I got to do?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Marry!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Marry?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Marry!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A girl with a million.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( he sinks back in his chair despondently )
sp.p: Say Harry, it's a shame to stir me up like this.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'm not stirring you up. I mean what I say.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, come off, do you suppose a girl with a million dollars would take a chance on me?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'm sure of it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What's the matter with her?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: There is no particular her. You can take your pick. I've no more idea who she is than you have.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What the devil are you getting at?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'll tell you. This is a pet scheme of mine. Have you ever lived in a small country town? A town with one measly hotel, about twenty stores and five churches.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, I have. Do you know what becomes of the young people who grow up in a place like that?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No — o!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Then let me tell you. The boys, who've got stuff in 'em, get out and become the biggest men in our cities. The Yaps stay there and clerk in father's store. But it's not so easy for the girls to get away. A few of them do by going to boarding schools and colleges and meeting and marrying some chaps from a City, but most of them have to stay at home. Why, by the time kids are old enough to think of getting married there isn't a small country town in America where you won't find four times as many girls as boys, and such boys! There isn't one in ten, that a girl who's got any sense at all could force herself to marry. Do you see? Demand forty
times the supply. Do you know there are twenty times as many good looking old maids in country towns as there are in the cities. It's a fact, because when they were young they couldn't lower themselves enough to accept what was left in the local market. Do you see what I'm getting at?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, you will in a moment. Now take a young chap from the city with a good appearance, educated, more or less of a gentleman, who doesn't talk like a Yap or walk like a Yap or dress like a Yap, or act like a Yap, thrown into such a town. Why I tell you there's nothing to it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It's wonderful to listen to you!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: It's good sense, anyway. Now, here you are, down on your luck, don't know how to earn your living, refusing to accept anything from your friends, ready to lie, steal, or murder to get some money, and on the other hand, here are hundreds of country heiresses with plenty of money for two, who you may easily fall in love with, leading the most unhappy lives. Now why not take one — and her money, make her happy, be happy yourself and be on Easy Street for the rest of your life?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( takes deep breath and turning front )
sp.p: I can't help thinking there's a catch in it somewhere.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Not if you follow my instructions. Everything depends on how you go at it. There are a lot of things to contend with at first But I'll show you how it can be done to a moral certainty.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Well, it's a pretty rotten thing deliberately starting out to marry a woman for her money —
( turns back to HARRY)
but it isn't rotten enough to stop me. What have I got to do?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Then you'll try it!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'll try anything.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Well, then, first pick out your town, one of about two thousand inhabitants. Most all of 'em have a few rich men with daughters, but we'll make
sure of that when we select one. Of course the town that is the suburb of a city is barred.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Oh, they don't count. The girls in 'em always know people in the City and that spoils the game.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Now here's the hard part for you, but necessary to make it a sure thing.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, here are things you mustn't do — you mustn't —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Wait a minute.
( takes out note-book and writes as HARRY talks )
mustn't do —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
You mustn't swear or use slang, you mustn't smoke and you mustn't drink.
(NAT suddenly looks up at HARRY)
It might be fatal if you were ever known to go into the hotel bar. And, for a time, you mustn't accept any invitations to dances, parties or even Sunday dinners.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Why Sunday dinners?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Sunday is the only day you'll be invited. Dinner on week days is from 12 to 12:30 and no time for guests.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Now here are the things you must do.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Go on.
(NAT begins writing again )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You must dress faultlessly but quietly. Clothes all dark and plain but the very best style, in fact, the best of everything, shirts, collars, ties, hats, socks, shoes, underwear —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Ain't I apt to be raided?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You must keep your shoes polished, be clean shaven and manicured.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( whose face has grown more and more gloomy )
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: No, you must work!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looks at HARRY and then turns away )
sp.p:
I
knew there was a catch in it. You mean I must get a job?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That settles it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Oh, no, I'll tell you how easy enough. And then, to cinch the whole business you must go to church!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: That's the most important thing of all.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Does going to church make a hit with a country girl?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: It makes the biggest kind of a hit with her popper and mommer, and that's very necessary when you're looking for their money. You must work and you must go to church.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Can't you think of something more?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Church and work are the biggest parts of the game, but you've only got to keep them up until you've landed what you're after. As soon as you get to your town hunt up some old woman who'd like to take a boarder; make arrangements with her and move in. Be sure and find one who talks a lot so she'll tell the neighbors all about you. Don't worry about that, though, they all talk! When you've located, stock up your room with about twenty of the driest looking books in the world, have drawing instruments, pencils, pens, red and black ink and all that sort of thing on the table, and make the room look as if you were the most profound student ever. Be sure and have a well worn Bible too.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'm going to have a swell time I can see that.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Next make the rounds of the stores and ask for work. Try and get into the dry goods store if you can. The girls all shop there, but anything will do except a grocery or a hardware store or places like that. You mustn't take any job where you'll soil your clothes or get your hands rough.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'd have a fine chance to cop out a millionaire's daughter if I was a ribbon clerk, wouldn't I?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: The best in the world! The ribbon clerk is the social equal of the rich girls in towns like those. He calls her Mary and she calls him Joe.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: All right. I'll be a dry goods clerk. What next?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: The store keepers are not apt to employ you at first, they'll be suspicious of you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I dare say.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: But don't let that worry you. Just call and say, "I'm looking for employment."

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: "I'm looking for employment."

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, but don't press it. Say it and go out.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: "Say it and go out." I can get that right easy. It's always that way when I ask for work.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: They'll send for you after a time. When they see you'll draw trade. And every Sunday, church! Pick out the one the rich people go to. Go in quietly and do just as they do. Stand up and sit down, look up the hymns and sing. Be careful not to look as if you were trying to show off. Don't sing too loud or anything like that, but do it all modestly, as if you were used to it. Better go to church here two or three times and get the hang of it. Now nearly all the wealthy old ducks in those towns are church deacons and though they might not speak to you for months on the outside, it's their business after church is over to shake hands with you, hope you enjoyed the sermon and ask you to come again, and they'll all take notice of you from that time on.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No wonder they made you a partner!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Now if you follow these rules not only will all the girls in town be falling over themselves to get you, but their fathers and mothers will be helping them. Then all you've got to do is to pick
out the one with the most coin and let her propose to you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Let her propose to me?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Let her propose to you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Whew! How am I going to live until I get in the dry goods store?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'll stake you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No you won't. I wouldn't —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Now stop! It's not the slightest risk, if you'll play the game out. For a while the dullness will drive you half crazy.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I don't mind the dullness.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Then listen; to-morrow go to the tailors and furnishers and don't pike about it. Get plenty and the best of everything, and I'll pay for it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Now see here.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Wait — this is a business proposition. No friendship in it. You give me your word of honor to see this through and faithfully follow instructions and after you are married to pay me a thousand dollars beside what I advance you and I'll consider it a mighty good deal for myself.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You really mean it?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Every word of it!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Then I'll go you. Word of honor.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Right you are. You can be ready in two weeks' time. I'll get you your wardrobe and give you five hundred dollars cash. That's more than you can spend if you don't get any job.

div.stage: (ROBBINS enters L., with two cocktails on tray .)

sp.speaker: ROBBINS.
sp.p:
Dinner, sir!
( offers cocktails )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, here's to the fortune hunter!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: God help the the future Mrs. Duncan!

div.stage: CURTAIN.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: [Figure: 101KB

SCENE: — SAMUEL GRAHAM'S drug store in Radville, Pa. It is a desolate and dilapidated old store, the soiled and faded paper cracking off the wall in spots. Village street backing . Window up R. in which are several old bottles and odds and ends, sponges, moth-balls, etc. Two gas jets for lighting up the window. Old hat rack to L. of window on the wall. Up R., inside of window, old work bench with various tools and a model of some sort. Underneath the bench is some sort of an arrangement looking like a dentist's laughing gas arrangement with pipes leading to a small tank. A rubber hose leads from this tank to a gas jet just above it . ( This gas jet is practical, being the one BURNHAM lights during the ACT.) Up R. C. is an old bench made out of a couple of saw horses with a model of one of MR. GRAHAM'S inventions. Old chair in front of work bench. An old stove down C. with pipe leading off ( Overhead ) to L. An old chair to L. of it and an old box to R. of it. Up L. is an old prescription counter with several large bottles all of which are empty or nearly so and an old cigar case with the glass broken, several packages and an old candle holder with candle . L. and running obliquely up and down stage is soda counter with a practical tap, with glasses and holders and a few bottles all of which are empty except one which is about half full of vanilla syrup. Behind soda and prescription counters are rows of dirty shelves with numerous bottles of various sizes most of which are empty. On lower shelf of row behind the soda counter is a flask of whiskey and a whiskey glass . Down R. is door leading to the street with the name of S. GRAHAM on the door — half of the letters are missing .. On L. is door leading to office. On this door is some lettering which was once "Office" but now looks like "Of ic."
TIME: — June. A quarter to twelve — Noon .
DISCOVERED: — WATTY and HI seated at stove C. WATTY L. on old box and HI R. on old chair .

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: Yes sir, he's the poorest man in this town.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: Yes, I guess he is.

div.stage: (BETTY enters from Office door L. with a jug and box and old papers. Puts jug and box on counter L. and puts papers into stove C.)

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: Where's your father gone, Betty?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
He was going over to the bank to see Mr. Lockwood and I don't know where else.
( at stove )

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p:
I don't envy him his call on Blinky Lockwood none.
( laughs )

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p:
Maybe he's depositin' his coupons. Is that it?
(HI and WATTY laugh . BETTY looks up sharply )

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Perhaps they're going to charge rent to the ones who sit around here all day.

div.stage: (TRACEY enters R., crosses to BETTY L.)

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.stage: ( rising and knocking pipe against stove )
sp.p: There, there, now, Betty! Don't get sarcastical. 'Tain't pretty in a young girl.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Note for you
from the Lockwood's, Betty, Josey asked me to bring it around.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: From the Lockwoods? for me?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Yah ha! It's an invitation. I got four more to take. I've got five more but one of 'em's for me.
( turns and goes R.)
Hope you'll have a good time when it comes off.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: But what is it Tracey?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: It tells in the invitation; g'bye.

div.stage: (TRACEY exits . BETTY opens note, reads it and puts it into pocket, then goes up to counter and works C.)

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: That's to the party Josie's a givin'; It'll be the biggest time you ever see.

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: I figger she's a gettin' it up fer that New York Dood.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: Duncan?

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: Ya ha.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: I didn't know he was 'quainted with the Lockwood's.

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: I didn't know he was 'quainted with nobody.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: Wal; he's durned curious — he's boardin' with Hetty Carpenter and she says he's allis a settin' in his room a study in' and studyin' and a studyin' — nobody ever hardly sees him 'cept in church.

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: I claim he's a 'spicious character.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p:
Don't look to me as though he knew enough to be much of anything.
( chuckling )

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: If he's a sure 'nough student and there ain't no outs about 'im, what in tarnation is he doin' here? That's what I'd like to have somebody tell me.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: Hetty says he wants a quiet place to study.

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p:
Oh, fiddle, you don't ketch no Noo York young feller a settlin' down in Radville 'less he's
crazy or somethin' worse but tain't no use tellin' Hetty Carpenter that, if anybody says a word again' him, she shuts 'em righ up.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p:
'Tain't only Hetty, but all the women's on his side. That's proof enough to me he ain't right.
( going up, seeing BETTY)
What do you think about him, Betty?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
I haven't seen him.
( both men regard her with astonishment )

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: Ain't seen him? Why he's been here more'n a month Ain't seen him? Well, don't you waste no more time adoin' it. He's a terrible dood.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
I don't want to see him.
( exits into office )

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.stage: ( coming down to R. of stove and sits in chair . HI is L. C. filling his pipe )
sp.p: I've pressed some o' his clothes when he was livin' at the hotel. I never see such clothes. Such goods and linin's.

div.stage: (BETTY enters .)

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p:
Roland Barnette says they ain't stylish though. Too much like an undertaker's git up
( lights pipe )

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p:
Well, Roland oughter know — he's the fanciest dressed up feller in the county.
( sits on box L. of stove )

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: When this cuss Duncan fust come here everybody but me figgered he had stacks of money — guess they're singin' a different tune now since he's been goin' around to the stores askin' for work.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p: Yes I guess they be.

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: He come into Leonard's yesterday and asked for a job but the minit Len looked up at him he turned right around and snuk out without a waitin' for Len to say a word. He's the curiousest critter we ever had in this town.

sp.speaker: WATTY.
sp.p:
Yes, I guess he is.
( clock strikes twelve )
That's noon. I'll go.

sp.speaker: HI.
sp.p: Well, I'll go with you.

div.stage: (LOCKWOOD enters .)

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Good mornin'.

sp.speaker: WATTI and HI.
sp.p:
Good mornin' Mr. Lockwood.
( they exit )

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Where's your father?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( who is kneeling in front of counter )
sp.p: He went to the bank to see you.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Oh he did, did he? Did he have anything for me?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I don't know sir. I'm afraid not.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Well, if he didn't there's no use seein' me. It won't do any good

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I guess he knows that.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
He does, eh? Well that's a good thing. Saves talk.
( looking around )
You don't do no business here, not to speak of, do ye?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
No sir, not to speak of.
( then with a desire to thank him, rising )
Oh, Mr. Lockwood, Josie sent me an invitation to her party.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
She has — has she? Huh!
( short unpleasant laugh, then goes up, glancing quickly and keenly around the store — BETTY goes behind the counter with pail )
Your father's still fooling with his inventions, ain't he — what's he inventin' now?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
I don't know what it is.
( pointing up R.)
There's the model he's working on.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.stage: ( goes to model R. and looks it over disdainfully )
sp.p: Foolishness! Why don't you tell him not to waste his time this way?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Because he likes it.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: What difference does it make? It don't bring him nothin' does it?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No sir!

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Nor do any good.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
No siree, it don't. He oughter stop it. What does he do with these things?
( pointing to models )
When he gets them finished?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: That's it, nothin' — nor never did, did he?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
When he had money he used to get them patented; but he can't any more.
( coming down below counter )

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Not much he can't. He used to get that money from me. I thought at fust there might be somethin' in 'em. I oughter have known better.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: He wouldn't a got money from you if he hadn't thought he could pay it back.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: No nor if I hadn't thought he could —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Huh!
( glances at him angrily and exits L. LOCKWOOD turns R. as if to go . ROLAND BARNETT enters with MR. BURNHAM R. BARNETT stops surprised upon seeing LOCKWOOD)

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Oh, I didn't know you were here, sir.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Yes — you needn't bother with this matter — I'll 'tend to it myself.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
I didn't come to see about the note — Sam was over to the bank to see you about that.
(BURNHAM comes down R. of BARNETT)
Oh Mr. Lockwood, let me introduce you to a friend of mine, Mr. Burnham from New York.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.stage: ( crossing to ROLAND. Shaking hands with LOCKWOOD)
sp.p: How are you?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: How de do?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: I brought Mr. Burnham over to see Sam about —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.stage: ( breaking in suddenly and with warning glance at BARNETT)
sp.p:
Yes, Barnett's been showing me around town a bit.
( crosses to LOCKWOOD)
Pretty little place, I think.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Here on business?

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Oh no, not exactly. Just looking about.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Only "looking" eh?

div.stage: (BURNHAM sees the wink from LOCKWOOD'S affected eyes and looks at him uncertainly .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Ah, ha, that's all —
(LOCKWOOD winks again )
Why — don't you believe it?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
I don't see no reason why I shouldn't.
( going to door )
I hope you'll like what you see. Good day.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: So long, Mr. Lockwood.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Be back at the Bank at one, Roland.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Oh yes sir — I'm always on time.

div.stage: (LOCKWOOD with a grunt at BARNETT'S last remark exits R. briskly .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: What was he winking at me for?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: He wasn't winking — he couldn't help doing that — it's a twitching he's got in his eye — that's why they call him Blinky Lockwood.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Oh, that was it.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Say he's got so much money he can't count it.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Well, he looks as if he'd always hang onto it.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Don't you be so sure about that — I'm as good as engaged to his daughter.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Is that so? Has he got more than one?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
No, Jose's an only child.
(BETTY comes out of office . BARNETT turns and sees her. To BETTY)
Your father about?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No but he'll be back any minute.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Burnham wants to see him right away. He's come clear from New York on purpose to —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.stage: ( stopping him abruptly and stepping in front of him )
sp.p:
Oh no, no —
( turning with a scowl. To BARNETT)
What's the matter with you?
(BARNETT goes up a little and leans on counter L. To BETTY again )
No, I happened to be in town and thought I'd like to have a little talk with your daddy, that's all. Nothing important, but if you know where to send for him —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( goes up R. takes off apron and gets hat )
sp.p: I guess I can find him.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: All right. Suppose you try.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Will you wait till I get back?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: 'Course we will.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: No use to give him my name, he doesn't know me.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
I'll tell him you're from New York, that'll be enough.
( exit )

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: You're a fine thing you are. First you came near telling the banker about this and then you start in with the daughter in a way that would make this old duck want a million for his burner.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.stage: ( laughing, sitting up on counter, swinging legs )
sp.p:
Oh, that needn't bother you. Sam Graham's the easiest thing in the world. Ask anybody in town if he ain't. He had plenty of money when he first came here and he's always worked hard, but he kept lendin' and lendin' and endorsin'
notes for people. He ain't got a penny now, and if you offer him anything for that burner he'll grab it, you see if he don't.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Broke, is he?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
I should say he was. Just look at this store.
(BURNHAM looks about. Going to BURNHAM)
and listen, we had a note of his come due at the bank yesterday, he can't pay it and Lockwood ain't goin' to renew it fer him.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Is that so?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
Sure.
( going up and looking about )
Say, I can show you that burner now. Maybe if you saw it work you wouldn't need to give him anything! I don't think it's patented.
(ROLAND goes R. to burner )

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
See here —
(ROLAND stops and turns — BURNHAM goes up to ROLAND)
I ain't a crook, get that in your head. Any deals I pull off, I pull off square. Besides I know it's patented. I looked it up.
( coming down )

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
See, there's the thing now.
(BURNHAM goes R. above stove and looks quickly at an object resembling a dentist's laughing gas arrangement , BARNETT goes to it explaining . BURNHAM goes R. below bench )
The oil goes here, this is the burner, he lights it here and the gas goes up through that pipe. There's one of the jets, look.
( points to gas jet on lower side of window )

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.stage: ( listens attentively to BARNETT and then crosses him to jet, looks into street, then strikes a match and turns on gas and lets it burn on instant then turns it off )
sp.p: Great guns!

div.stage: (GRAHAM comes down past windows, outside .)

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: It's all right, ain't it?

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Oh
well, it may amount to something.
( crosses R. C.)
It's hard to tell.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
Why I tell you it will revolutionize the whole —
( crossing L. C. Noise is heard at door )

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Sh — h — who's this?
( door opens )

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p:
That's him now.
( goes up R.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( enters, sees BURNHAM, smiles and nods pleasantly )
sp.p:
How de do, sir?
( goes up to put his hat away. Sees BARNETT)
Hello Roland.
(BARNETTE comes down between GRAHAM and BURNHAM)

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Say Sam —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Sh —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Oh nothing — I was — er — showing my friend Mr. Burnham, from New York, round town and we just happened to look in —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( coming down C. looking at BURNHAM)
sp.p:
Took this for the old curiosity shop perhaps. Won't you sit down, sir?
( pointing to chair at R. of stove )

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( pointing to box at L. of stove )
sp.p:
Try that box, Roland. It don't make a bad seat.
( going to L. toward office. Calling )
Betty! Betty. Where's she gone I wonder? She'd love to see someone from New York.
( turning back C.)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Oh we've seen her, Mr. Graham. She went out looking for you.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.stage: ( tactfully with proud look and wink at BURNHAM)
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Lockwood was here, guess that's what she wanted to find you for?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Lockwood! Did you tell him I'd been over to the bank to see him?

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Yes, I told him.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Mean business sometimes asking favors of these bankers eh? Mr. Graham?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Yes, it is unpleasant.
( confidingly )
There's a note of mine due and I'm not able to take care of it or pay the interest just now —
( pauses, thinks a moment and then adds pleasantly )
But Mr. Lockwood is kind — very kind.
(BURNHAM and BARNETT exchange glances )

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: I'm afraid you're a little too sure, Sam. When there's money due Lockwood, he wants it.

div.stage: ( There is a moment's pause, both men watch GRAHAM closely .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Barnett tells me you are quite an inventor, Mr. Graham.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
I've spent most of my life at it but nothing has turned out well —
( pause, then brighter )
Not so far I mean, but I may hit it yet.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: That's the way to talk. Never give up I say. You had a patent on a thrashing machine, didn't you?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, but I couldn't get anybody to take hold of it. You see I haven't any money Mr. Burnham.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Well, I'll talk to you about it sometime.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: You will?

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Yes. By the way you got your power from gas, is that right?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, but coal will do just as well. I got a patent on a burner that makes gas from crude oil. I thought it would be cheaper. I could get up steam mighty quick with that gas arrangement. I use it for lighting here now.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Well, I declare!

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Say Mr. Burnham, don't you think you could help Sam to —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: I think I could eat my dinner. Come along, let's go over to the hotel.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes Roland, don't starve your friend. I'm glad you looked in, sir.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: You'll call again I hope.

sp.speaker: BARNETT.
sp.p: Say, Mr. Burnham, if you'll —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
There that will do —
( to GRAHAM)
I may drop in if I have time on my way to the train and look over things.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I'd be glad to show you anything I've got here —

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: All right, good day — I'll see you again, perhaps.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Good day sir. Good day Roland.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Good-bye.

div.stage: (BURNHAM and BARNETT exit up R. outside of window slowly .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( stands alone in thought a moment )
sp.p: Mr. Lockwood over here — ah, well, he's kind, very kind.

div.stage: ( With a sigh he goes to table up R. on which is model and begins working . BURNHAM and BARNETT stop up at window and BARNETT points out and is talking about NAT as he comes along reading a book and then BURNHAM and BARNETT pass on . NAT looks about and puts book under his arm and looks into window again and then comes down and enters door R. He crosses to C.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Quite well, thank you.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( after pause without looking up and in very pleasant tone )
sp.p: Anything you want?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Would it be possible for me to speak to the proprietor for a moment?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I should judge it would. Go right along.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Might I ask, are you Mr. Graham?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes sir, that's me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looking up page in Act I note book and glancing at it )
sp.p: I'm looking for employment.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Employment?
( drops tools. Looks up then rises and goes to NAT)
Well I declare. You're the stranger the whole town has been talking about. I'm real glad to see you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
If at any time you should have an opening here that you can offer me I will endeavor to give satisfaction. Good day sir.
( crosses to door )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Are you in a hurry?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh no sir — only I mustn't press it. Just ask for it and go — I mean — I don't want to take up your time.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh well, don't let that worry you. If you're really looking for a job, I'd like to give you one first rate.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
You'd — you'd like to — oh —
( much surprised )
You don't mean it.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You're the first man I ever met who's felt that way about it.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: The trouble is my boy that my business is so small I don't need any help. There isn't much of anything to do here.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That's just the sort of a place I'd like.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I mean, I'm willing to take anything, no matter how little there is to do.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: This might suit you then.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I wish you'd let me try it.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: To tell you the truth sir, I can't afford it. When your pay was due I'm afraid I shouldn't have any for you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I don't mind that part.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Mr. Graham, if you'll teach me the drug business I'll work for you for nothing.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looks about a bit — then confidentially )
sp.p: Well between you and me, I've been here five weeks with nothing to do but look at a book and it's got me crazy enough to want to work.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, I swan! I'd better take you over to Sothern and Lee's. They'd be glad to get you at the price.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No I've been there. Why not here?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I'm afraid you wouldn't learn much. I don't do business enough to give you a good idea of it They get all the trade.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't you think if I came in here we could build up the business?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: No, I don't think so.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No! Of course not — you're right.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
I haven't got capital enough to get stocked up, that's the real trouble Folks have got into the habit of going to the other store because I'm out of so many things.
(NAT looking about store — turning to GRAHAM.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: How do you expect to do business unless you have things to sell?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
NAT.
sp.p: How much business do you do here now?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Some days I take in a dollar or two and some days nothing.
( pointing to fountain L.)
I fixed up my soda fountain last week and I'm getting a little out of that but I need some more syrups.
(NAT goes to fountain and looks it over )
I've only got vanilla.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Soda water — all the girls around here drink soda, don't they?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Mr. Graham, I wish you'd let me come in here for a time. I don't care about wages.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well my boy, it don't seem quite right to have you work here for nothing — but if you really want to do it, I'll be glad to have you and if times improve I'll be glad to pay you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That's fine. When can I start?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Whenever you like.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( going up and taking off gloves, etc. )
sp.p:
I'd like to now. Where can we get some syrup?
( puts books and gloves on show case )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Unfortunately I'll have to buy it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( putting hand in pocket and getting out money )
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh no, you mustn't do that — I couldn't allow it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I'm either asleep or someone is refusing to take money from me.
( coming down to GRAHAM R. C.)
Oh, that's all right, I'll draw it down as soon as we sell some soda. Will five dollars be enough?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh my yes, but it isn't right for me —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Nonsense, how can we build up trade without syrup?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: And how can I learn the business without trade?

div.stage: ( Closing GRAHAM'S hand over the money. Goes up R. C.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( giving up argument and spreading out bill and looking at it )
sp.p:
My oh my — I'll have to write to Elmira for it.
( putting bill in vest pocket )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: We'll telegraph for it.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Telegraph? That would kill Lew Parker I guess.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Who's he?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Telegraph operator and ticket agent. No. I'll write a letter. I think that will do.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
All right but tell them to send it at once and send it C. O. D. We'll have to clean up the store a little. We'll put out some signs, eh?
( coming down L. C.)
We've got to get the people in the habit of coming here somehow.
( turning back to GRAHAM looks up at shelves )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: You have splendid business ability.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I say you have great business ability.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'll write that to my chum.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, I can see that you have. Now — I — well, I've been a failure in business. I've been a failure in everything as far as that goes.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( after looking at the old man a moment holds out his hand )
sp.p:
Let's shake hands.
(GRAHAM looks up )
For luck.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: My boy — you are — it's very kind of you to buy the syrup — very kind —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
That's because I've got great business ability.
( turns L. then back to GRAHAM)
Have you got a broom? I'll clean up the store a little.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: The broom's in the cellar, I guess, but — your clothes would —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh that's all right. Where is the cellar?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Underneath —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Is there a stairway?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Oh yes, over there through the office.
( pointing L. NAT goes toward office . GRAHAM stops him )
Here, you'd better take a candle.
( goes up to get candle . TRACEY enters R. NAT goes to him C.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Huh?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Is there anything you wish to purchase?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: No ma'am!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Then will you be good enough to excuse me?
( turns and GRAHAM hands him a candle and after bowing to GRAHAM he exits L.)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( standing and watching NAT off. To GRAHAM)
sp.p: Is he workin' here?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
He intends to.
(TRACEY makes a rush for the door )
What did you want, Tracey?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
I fergit.
( Exits quickly )

div.stage: (GRAHAM looks after TRACEY, then around at door where NAT went out, then shakes his head and smiles. Goes to bench R. and sits as BETTY comes in . BETTY enters suddenly, white with anger and goes up and hangs her hat behind GRAHAM. She begins the scene quietly but shows that self possession is causing her great effort .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Oh, Betty, I've got a piece of news for you. What do you think of our having —
( seeing her look )
why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Father — can you get me some money?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Why Betty — what has —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Can you get me some money?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well — er — how much?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Enough to buy a dress — a nice dress — a dress that will surprise folks.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Tell me what the matter is, Betty. Wanting a dress would never upset you like this.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Look at that.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Josie Lockwood's party — she sent you an invitation. Well, that was kind of her — very kind.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
No it was not kind — it was mean —
( goes U. R.)
It was mean .

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, Betty — now don't say that.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I heard the girls talking in the post-office. I was around by the boxes where they didn't see me, they were laughing because I was invited. They said the reason Josie did it was because she knew I wouldn't have anythin' to wear and she wanted to find out what excuse I'd make for not going.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, Betty, Betty, don't you mind what they say.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( taking invitation from GRAHAM, moving L.)
sp.p: Yes, I do mind. I can't help mindin'. I'm goin' to that party now and I'm going to have a dress to go in too.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, we'll see. I'll try —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: That means you can't help me?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, no. No it doesn't — I'll do what —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Have you got any money now?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well no — not at present.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: And you can't pay Mr. Lockwood what you owe him on the note, can you?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: No, not to-day, but he'll give me a little more time. He's kind, very kind.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Then if you should get any money you'd have to give it to him?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, I think it will come out all right.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Oh, what's the use of talkin' that way? I know you can't do anything for me and so do you.
( with savage resentment, coming back to GRAHAM C.)
I can't understand it.
(NAT appears in door L. with broom, stops undecidedly )
Why is it that I have to be more shabby, than any other girl in town? I don't mind cookin' and doin' the house work and all the rest but why is it that you never can give me anythin' at all? Why is it that everyone looks down on us and laughs at us and sneers at us?
( voice trembling )
Why is it half the time we don't have enough to eat? Other men can take care of their families and give their children things to wear. You have only us two to look after and you can't even do that. It isn't right and if I were you I'd be ashamed of myself —
( stops suddenly full of rage but secretly sorry for what she has said )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( rises slowly. Looks at her a moment and when he speaks his voice trembles )
sp.p:
Why, Betty — I — I —
( brightens with an effort. Rises )
Oh, but things are going to be better soon. You must have a little more patience.
( with sudden thought )
Why there was a gentleman here this morning from New York City talking about an invention of mine.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Invention! Oh, father! Everybody knows they're no good. You've been wastin' time on them ever since I can remember and you've never sold one yet.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
But this gentleman seemed quite interested. He's over at the hotel now.
( starting R.)
I'll go over and have a talk with him, you wait here —
( turns and sees NAT)
Oh, this gentleman is
going to be with us in the store. This is my daughter Mr. —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Duncan: Nathaniel Duncan. How do you do Miss Graham?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( in great astonishment, forgetting to return bow )
sp.p:
Goin' to be with us?
(GRAHAM goes up stage for hat )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Why, yes — Your father has been kind enough to take me in. I'm to be the soda clerk.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
You wait here, Betty, till I get back.
( exits R.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( has his trousers turned up at the bottom and has a broom and dust-pan. There is a long pause . BETTY not recovered from her surprise stares at him steadily , NAT smiles sweetly )
sp.p:
I — I'm going to sweep, if you don't mind. You'll excuse me won't you?
( sweeps )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: You don't really intend to work here?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That is my intention — yes —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( annoyed at his tone, thinks he is making fun of her, says sharply )
sp.p: Where do you think your pay will come from?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Heaven perhaps.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Huh! You're making a mistake. Father can't pay you anythin'.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: He'll pay me all I'm worth .

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Of course he thinks he can. But he can't. You don't know him.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( stands broom against counter, coming down C. to BETTY)
sp.p:
I'm afraid it's you who don't know him —
( suddenly dropping ministerial air and tone and speaking naturally and sincerely, crosses to her )
I'm going to give you a little advice, Miss Graham. Don't speak to your father again as you did just now.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: What business is it of yours?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: None, but just the same I wouldn't if I were you.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Well you're not me, understand that? When I want advice from you I'll ask for it and until I do, you let me alone. I know why you talk that way.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Do you?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Yes, I do you!
( she hurls the following at him as fast as she can speak )
You go to church all the time and try to make out you're too religious for anythin' and you like to hear yourself giving Christian advice to poor miserable sinners, you think it's just too lovely of you, that's why you said it if you want to know. Folks wonder what you're doing here. I could tell them. You're here to show off your good clothes and your finger-nails and the way you part your hair and all the other things you do that nobody in New York would pay any attention to.
( stops breathlessly )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
A pretty good guess at that.
( gets broom and sweeps again at L.)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( surprised at his answer and somewhat mollified in spite of herself C. facing front )
sp.p: Oh, yes, it's easy enough to give advice when you've got plenty of money and fine clothes.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I know that. But the only reason I spoke was because I'm strong for your father — and I wanted to do you a good turn too.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I don't want any of your good turns.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Then I apologize — only think over what I said sometime.
( sweeping )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I had a good reason for saying what I did to him.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I know you had.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( surprised. Looking over shoulder at NAT)
sp.p: You know I had. Well how do you know?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( coming down to L. of her — takes broom with him. Lightly leans on it )
sp.p:
Because I've been up against it myself for five years and I know how it Seels to see other people getting along when you're not
getting along; to know they have things you don't have. Why I've kept out of the way for days and days rather than to let my successful friends see how shabby I looked. Many a time I've run across the street to avoid meeting some pal who I knew would invite me to have dinner or luncheon or a drink — of soda — or something for fear he would find out that I couldn't "treat" in return. Many a time I've gone hungry and slept in the park until an old friend found me and took me home with him.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: And your old friend started you on the road to fortune?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: He said so. But it's your father I want to talk about. Now I'll bet he knows more than any other man in this town and besides that he's a fine, square, good-hearted old gentleman, anyone can see that — only he has one awful fault, he doesn't know how to make money and that's mighty tough on you; but when you roast him for it you only make him feel as miserable as a yellow dog and doesn't help matters a bit. He can't change into a sharp business crook now, he's too old a man. Before long he — he won't be with you at all and when he's gone you'll be sore on yourself — sure — if you keep on throwing it into him as you did just now —

div.stage: (BETTY stands looking at him . NAT turns away. Begins sweeping — up stage .)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I — I won't do it again.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Bully for you.
( sees JOSIE LOCKWOOD and ANGIE at window )
Sh — customers.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
They've come to see you. Tracey's told them you're here.
(JOSIE and ANGIE are at the door )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: The tall one's old Lockwood's daughter, isn't she?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Yes, she's an heiress.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Then she's the one.
( goes up L. turns down trousers, etc. )

div.stage: (JOSIE and ANGIE enter .)

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Oh, here's Betty now.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: How de do, Betty?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( crossing to door R. speaking to both but with no cordiality )
sp.p: Hello.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Did you get the invitation?
( winking slyly at ANGIE who grins )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: The invitation?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Why I sent you one. To the party you know.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Did you?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I gave it to Tracey for you. Didn't you. get it?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Oh, perhaps I did.
( Exits R. leaving the girls staring after her )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Well, did you ever?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( coming down referring to his note book and replacing it in his pocket )
sp.p:
May I have the honor of waiting upon you ladies?
( both GIRLS turn as if surprised to see him )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Oh, ha, ha, ha, how do, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Good afternoon.
( bows to each separately. They watch him with admiring surprise )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
We thought we'd like some soda.
(NAT, a little startled, not knowing how to draw soda )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Yes, it's so warm — we —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Yes, certainly.
( looks around an instant then goes up behind counter )
Will you step this way, please?
( the girls look at each other and laugh and go to fountain )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
What'll you have — er — would — would you prefer soda or vanilla?
( girls laugh as if it were a great joke )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, I hate vanilla.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: I do too.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh don't say that. Of course there is vanilla and vanilla. Some vanilla I know is detestable but when you get a really fine — er — imported vanilla, it is quite — er — particularly at this season of the year —

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, is it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It is indeed, no doubt of it. Especially just now, right after the Bock season — er — I mean when the weather is — is — in a way — vanilla weather.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: I like chocolate best.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Well, I'll have the vanilla.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Thank you very much —
( he looks on shelf behind and finally on lower shelf finds whiskey bottle with glass on top, he sets the glass down and smells of the bottle find is surprised at smell of whiskey )
Oh —

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I believe it's whiskey.
(ANGIE goes up stage. The girls look at each other . NAT looks about counter, finding several empty bottles with metal caps on the necks. All the bottles are empty except the one which contains the vanilla. He passes her the vanilla bottle and the whiskey glass. The girls look at him in astonishment. Pause )
You — er — wanted vanilla, did you not?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Yes thanks, vanilla.
( another pause )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well — that's it.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I don't want to drink it clear — you mix it with the soda, you know?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Oh, you want to make a high-ball of it.
( both girls laugh )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.stage: ( going to soda counter and explaining )
sp.p: You see you put in the syrup first and then the soda.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Certainly.
( to JOSIE)
If you'll be kind enough to help yourself to the syrup.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh no, you do it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Certainly.
( puts syrup in whiskey glass )
Say "when".

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: What. Oh, don't put in any more.

div.stage: (NAT puts the glass under the tap and tries to work it with no success. The girls, getting interested, come nearer. Suddenly the soda spurts out with such force that it sprays them and the girls jump back, looking themselves over .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( takes out hankerchief and tries to remove soda off his clothes and face. Apologetically )
sp.p:
Our soda is so strong, you know.
( getting apron and putting it on around his neck )
Now, if you will step over there out of danger, I'll try again.
( the girls go R. NAT takes a large glass this time and turns tap carefully and the soda runs into the glass without any force. Looking up and smiling )
I think it's safe now, I seem to have it under control.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.stage: ( going U. L. and suddenly changing the subject )
sp.p: We've seen you at church, Mr. Duncan.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Do you have to go too?

sp.speaker: JOSIE and ANGIE.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I mean, do you attend regularly?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Oh, yes.
( looks at NAT admiringly )
You make it a rule to go every Sunday, don't you, Mr. Duncan?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It's one of the rules, but I didn't make it.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Won't you join the choir, Mr. Duncan? I want you to awfully.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Do you?
( offering them the sodas )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: All the girls want him to — don't they, Angie?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Choir?
( takes out note book and looks at it )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Oh yes honestly — they're all just dying to meet you.
( they take up the glasses )
