sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, I'll have to write and ask first.

div.stage: ( The girls taste the soda and look at each other peculiarly . NAT watches them . ANGIE tastes soda and gives sudden ejaculation .)

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I sincerely hope it's not so very had.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Do you like it Josie?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.stage: ( looks around and sees NAT watching her and smiles )
sp.p:
Mine is perfectly lovely only it isn't very sweet.
(JOSIE sets it down only having tasted it )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I made them dry, you know.
( the girls don't understand. Picking up JOSIE'S glass and moving toward tap )
I'll put a collar on for you.
( she motions him not to put any more in )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh no, thank you.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.stage: ( going to counter and setting down her glasses )
sp.p: Why don't you try a glass, Mr. Duncan?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'm on the wagon.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I mean I don't drink at all. It's one of the rules.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Come on, Josie, we must go, we've been here ever so long.
(JOSIE looks at her, annoyed )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, don't hurry I beg of you.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh; we haven't hurried. Remember what I said about the choir, won't you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( trying to assume a lover's attitude )
sp.p: I shall never forget it.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Good-bye.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Not good-bye I trust.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, I'll be in again. Oh, my land; I'd forgotten all about paying for the soda.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: The idea!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't speak of it please.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Oh yes, indeed!
( opening purse )
How much is it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I beg pardon.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: For the soda?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh! Why — er — two for a quarter.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Ain't you funny!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: It's ten cents, isn't it, Mr. Duncan?

div.stage: [(SPERRY, a drummer enters and goes R. He is a quiet, old-fashioned, pleasant-voiced man about 45. NAT crosses below the girls to door and holds it open for them .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Thank you very much.
( at door as GIRLS pass out )
Good afternoon, ladies. You'll call again, won't you?
(ANGIE goes out first )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Thank you, I'm sure.
(SPERRY is looking NAT over )

div.stage: ( After GIRLS exeunt NAT closes the door and looks at money juggling it a bit and smiling . SPERRY comes down to R. of stove )

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Old Sam about?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No Mr. Graham isn't here at present.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Are you working here?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Well, I'll be hanged!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Is there anything I can do for you?

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: No — n — thank you — just the same.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: We have some fine, fresh drawn vanilla.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: No, I don't buy from drug stores. I sell to them.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
My card!
( sits R. of stove )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Mr. Sperry?

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Yes, I don't make this town very often. Sothern and Lee are the only people I sell to here but I never miss a chance to chin awhile with old Sam and I had about ten minutes before train time.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Mr. Graham doesn't buy of you, then?
( goes L. to counter )

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Don't buy of anybody, does he?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I don't know I've just come here.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Oh well, Sam's a nice old duffer but he ain't got no business sense. Everything's run down here. You can see for yourself and Sothern and Lee have got all the trade.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't you think Mr. Graham could get some of the trade if he was stocked up?

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: He'd get the biggest part of it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Do you think so?
( comes over C.)

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
Yes, I'm sure of it.
( nodding )
Everybody likes Sam you know. I talked to our people a little while ago about giving some more credit.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: But they wouldn't do a thing. You see he owes them a bill now that's so old it's got whiskers on it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: How much is this old bill?

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: About fifty dollars, I think.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( gets box from L. of stove and sits L. of SPERRY)
sp.p:
Suppose you told your firm that there's a young fellow here who'd like to give this store a
boom. Say he wants a little credit because — because Mr. Graham wouldn't allow him to put up any cash —

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: No, I'm afraid they wouldn't.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: How much is this bill with the whiskers?

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Forty-seven dollars and thirty cents.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Now suppose I pay that —

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Pay it? Do you really mean it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Certainly I mean it.
( pulling out roll of bills and handling it so SPERRY sees several one hundred dollar bills )

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Quite a roll you're carrying.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
No, only a trifle, a mere trifle. I don't take much cash around with me. Haven't for five years.
( pulls a $50 bill from roll and holds it )
What do you think they'd say —

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: I guess you could have what you wanted in moderation. Can I give them your name?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Duncan. Nathaniel Duncan.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Any business connections?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: None that I care to speak about.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Anyone you can refer them to?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Do you know L. J. Bartlett &.mp; Co.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
The brokers?
(NAT nods "yes" )
Do I know J. P. Morgan?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, let them inquire of Kellogg the junior partner? He knows me.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Kellogg! That's enough, if he says you're all right, you can have anything you want?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Here's fifty-
( turns away and picks up box )
That's funny. I couldn't do that for myself.
(NAT puts box L. of stove again )

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.stage: ( putting $50 in pocket — taking out small bills and change and counting it )
sp.p: No, I suppose such a small matter wouldn't interest you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, I suppose not.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
Two-seventy.
(NAT puts change in his pocket )
Now, let me see, what do you want here?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
What?
(SPERRY nods toward shelves . NAT goes L. thinking )
Oh, well, I want a lot of pills — and —
( seeing SPERRY smile at him )
— every thing for a regular drug store. Everything Sothevn &.mp; Lee carry and some things they don't, only all in small lots until I see what we sell.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: If you'll leave it to me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That's a funny thing. That's just what I'm going to do. You know what we need here as well as I do, don't you?

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Oh yes, indeed. I'll get up a list of all the things you'll want and have the goods shipped here to-morrow.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Splendid!

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
Well, I must be getting down to the depot.
( goes to door and meets GRAHAM, who is just coming in )
Why, hello, Sam, glad to see you.
( shaking hands )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Hello Sperry, how de do? I'm glad to see you too. This gentleman is Mr. Duncan.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Yes, we've been talking.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Mr. Sperry is going to stock us up here if you're willing.
(GRAHAM looks at him in great astonishment )
Are you?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( looks from one to the other )
sp.p: But Sperry knows I'm not able to —

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: That's all right, Sam. Mr. Duncan has made me realize that if you've got the goods here you can sell 'em.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: So he'll put in what we need and we'll pay for them as fast as we can.

div.stage: (GRAHAM with great feeling looking from one to the other, too overcome to say anything .)

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
I'll get the goods right away, Sam, and I'll be around again next month — Good day, Mr. Duncan. So long, Sam.
( shaking hands heartily )
Congratulations, again.
( aside to GRAHAM)
That's a smart young man you got there.
( nodding knowingly toward NAT. Exits )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I don't know what to say to you, my boy, I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, it's nothing, sir.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: But how did you —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, I just gave that drummer a little talk and he agreed to it.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: You're a wonderful business man —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'll begin to believe that if you keep on saying it. What shall I do with this ten cents?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I sold some soda —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, I declare!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Where's the cash drawer?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Over there, behind the counter.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( goes up behind counter, and holds coin over drawer )
sp.p:
Now listen!
( drops coin and as it jingles into drawer, both laugh, lookng over the shelves )
I wish we could get some paint — these — shelves —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, that's easy enough — I've got some over at the house — That gentleman from New York is coming over right after dinner. I wonder if Betty — went home!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I'd like to tell her of this good fortune. Poor little girl; she felt pretty bad to-day because she didn't have a dress for Josie Lockwood's party.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( putting hand in pocket. Stops and hastily withdraws it again as if he had burned his fingers, then as if speaking to his finger )
sp.p:
Keep away from
there.
( goes up L. Door opens quickly and PETE WILLING, SHERIFF, enters noisily, goes R. C.)

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Say, Sam, see here a minute!

div.stage: (NAT is up L. cleaning up .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Hello, Sheriff, how de do? Have a chair!

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: I'm sorry about this, Sam, hut there ain't no use wastin' words about it, I'm here on business. You know you had a note due at the bank yesterday, don't you?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, but —

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Well, it's protested and I'm here to serve the papers onto ye.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Why, Pete?
( half dazed )
Oh, there must be some mistake, somewhere. I'll go over and see Mr. Lockwood. He'll arrange it for me, I'm sure.
( starts up to get hat )

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: No, Mr. Lockwood don't want to see you unless you can settle.

div.stage: (NAT quickly feeling for the bills, in his pocket, starts down, stops C. Thinks a moment, slowly withdraws his hand, shakes his head and goes up again .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Mr. Lockwood — said — he didn't want to see me.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: That's just what he said and I got orders from him soon's I got judgment to close you up.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( near door R. smiling but lips trembling )
sp.p: To — to turn me out of the store?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
Now, there ain't no use whining about it.
(NAT starts down quickly )
Law is law and —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Wait! Are you laboring under the impression that Mr. Graham is deaf?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: He said "what." Did you hear it?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: What have you got to do with it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'll show you what I've got to do with it If you tell me the amount of that note.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.stage: ( after a pause and in lower key )
sp.p: With interest and costs it figgers up three hundred and ninety dollars and eighty-two cents.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Three hundred and ninety dollars?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Yes, three hundred and ninety — dollars and say — you look ahere —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Here, listen, if there is anything else you've got to tell me go out in the middle of the street and tell me from there.
( puts his hand in his pocket and pulls out roll of bills so that the audience sees it, but not PETE and GRAHAM. He goes up to cash drawer and opens it )
Three hundred and ninety —
( he apparently gets the roll out of drawer . PETE is about to speak but seeing bills stops in great surprise . GRAHAM is dumbfounded at the sight . NAT comes down counting off one hundreds )
One, two, three, four.
(PETE backs up a bit with astonishment. Taking off his hat )
Four hundred, Mr. Sheriff. Will you kindly give me that note and the change and then place yourself on the other side of that door?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: I ain't got the note with me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Perhaps you'd better go over to the bank and get it.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: All right, I'll go and get it. Can I have the money?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( coming toward him and holding out money and as he is about to take it )
sp.p:
Wait a minute — are you a regular Sheriff?
(PETE shows his badge )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
It's beautiful.
( gives him the bills and PETE looks at the bills and at NAT and then starts to door R.)

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.stage: ( as he gets near door, looks at money again. Exit slamming the door )
sp.p: Well I'll be dommet!

div.stage: (GRAHAM watches NAT a moment, has been too dazed to interfere while PETE was there .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Why, I can't allow you to do this, my boy —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't feel that way about it. It's done.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I'll turn the store over to you if —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Oh, Lord no — please don't do that —
( going to GRAHAM R.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Then I can't accept your great kindness, my boy, unless you think a partnership would —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
That's the way to do it, a partnership.
( as GRAHAM is about to speak again )
Now don't say any more about it. Now you said you had some paint. These shelves —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Yes, at the house. I'll get it.
( almost breaking down )
If — if — Fate — or — something hadn't brought you here to-day I don't know what would have happened to Betty and me. Perhaps to a gentleman of your wealth, four hundred dollars don't mean much —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, nothing.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
To me it's meant everything. I only hope I can repay you some day. God bless you, my boy, God bless you.
( goes out R.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( watches GRAHAM go out and then counts over the few dollars he has left, sadly, and returns them to his pocket )
sp.p:
Harry said I couldn't get rid of that stake in a year. He doesn't know what a fast town this is.
( he starts up as LOCKWOOD comes down past window. He sees LOCKWOOD)
Father-in-law — I must be a business man.
( goes up L. bus. of mixing bottles and boxes )

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.stage: ( enters and goes L. C. sees NAT. Very genial manner )
sp.p: You're Mr. Duncan, ain't you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Yes, sir.
(LOCKWOOD looks at him familiarly. Coming down )
Oh, Mr. Lockwood, I believe?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Yes. I'm glad to meet you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Pete Willin' was tellin' me you'd just took up this note of Graham's.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Well, here's some change that's coming to you and if you'll have Sam step over to the Bank they'll give him the note.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: I'm glad you're comin' in here with. Sam.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It's only temporary. I am devoting much of my time to my studies but I feel that I should be earning something too.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: That's right — you always go to church, don't you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, sir, only Sundays.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: That's what I mean. Do you drink?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Oh, no, sir. Don't drink, smoke or swear and on Sundays I go to church. Dress quietly hut neatly — don't accept invitations to —
( turning to LOCKWOOD)

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: I'm mighty glad to hear it. I'm at the head of the temperance movement here and I hope you'll join us — Set an example to our fast young men.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, I'm sure I can set an example to them.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.stage: ( looks about for some little way to show his friendship )
sp.p:
Warm to-day.
( takes off hat and fans himself )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, sir, very.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: I believe I'll have a glass of soda.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Yes, sir, certainly.
( goes behind counter L.)

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: I suppose you'll fix this place up some, eh?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, yes — we'll try to have the best drug store in the State, would you like vanilla?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
No, just soda.
( for the first time NAT sees wink from LOCKWOOD'S affected eye )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looks at him, unable to believe his eyes )
sp.p: I beg pardon?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: I say, just plain — soda.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: On the level?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
What?
( winks again )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I understand.
( gets whiskey bottle, turns out drink and fills it with soda )

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.stage: ( takes a couple of swallows and smacks his lips, then drinks it all )
sp.p:
How can anyone want intoxicating liquors when they can get such a bracin' drink as this?
(NAT turns and picks up bottle and smells of it to make sure it's whiskey )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I pass.
(LOCKWOOD putting a nickel on counter for drink — goes down L. C. NAT looks at it )
Ten cents more, please.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Plain soda.
( winks )

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
Not much. Oh, I guess you're joking.
( down L. C. laughing )
Well, good luck to you, Mr. Duncan. Oh, say, you must come and see us some time.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Thank you very much, sir.
( coming down )
I had the pleasure of seeing your daughter in here a few moments ago. She is a charming girl.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
I'm real glad you think so. She's taken a great shine to you, too; seeing you at church. Come around and get acquainted. You're the sort of a young feller I'd like to have her know.
( looking NAT over )
Good day!
( crosses R. toward door, winks )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Good day and thank you again.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.stage: ( stops at door and turning to NAT)
sp.p:
Good-bye.
( winks again )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
That's all right. I won't say anything about it.
( after LOCKWOOD has gone NAT counts over his stake again, going L. Goes up behind counter. Resuming work of cleaning up . GRAHAM with paint and brushes enters with BURNHAM)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Yes, that's my business. Sometimes I've bought odd no-account things that have made me a lot of money and more times they never amount to anything, but that burner you got sort of struck my fancy.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, the gas arrangement?

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Yes. Such a curious idea I kind a took to it. It's patented ain't it?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

div.stage: (NAT listens .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Want to sell the patent?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Why yes, if you think it is worth anything.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Well, it might be sometime and then again it might not. I was thinking at dinner, I'd like to own that burner and I made out a little bill of sale and says I to myself: "If Graham will take Five hundred dollars for that thing," says I, "I'll give it to him, spot cash, right in his hand." Says I.
( taking paper and bills out )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Five hundred dollars!

div.stage: (NAT is watching them .)

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Yes, five hundred — cash
( coming down )
I guess you don't know it but I heard at the Bank they wasn't going to extend the
time on that note of yours and I thought this five hundred would come in handy and I wanted to help you out.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, that is kind of you, sir — everybody's being good to me to-day or else I'm dreaming.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Then it's a bargain?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Well, I hope you won't lose anything by it, Mr. Burnham.
(NAT forms the word "BURNHAM" with his lips but makes no sound, trying to remember where he heard the name )
Making gas from crude oil —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Gas from — by Jove!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: May come in handy in some places.

div.stage: (NAT comes down to L.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Mr. Graham, is this patent of yours for getting gas from crude oil?

div.stage: (BURNHAM looks up frowning .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Why yes, a burner that —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I wouldn't sell it just yet, if I were you.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: What are you butting into this for?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Because I'm a business Man — if you don't believe it, ask him.
( indicating GRAHAM)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: He has a perfect right to, Mr. Burnham.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: You haven't got any objections to him getting this money, have you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, but I want to look into the matter first.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, I have an idea you wouldn't offer five hundred dollars for this burner unless you expected to make something out of it and I think it ought to be worth as much to Mr. Graham as it is to you.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Aw, you don't know what you're talking about.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I know that, but I happen to know you are promoting a scheme for making gas from crude oil and you won't get this burner until I have consulted my friend, Henry Kellogg about it.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Henry Kellogg?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, of L. J. Bartlett &.mp; Co.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: Oh, well, if you're representing Kellogg, I've got nothing to say, only why the devil did he send you here?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I am ashamed to tell you. Better ask him.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p: That's what I will do the moment I see him and you can bet on that.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, I can't, I'm not allowed to gamble.

sp.speaker: BURNHAM.
sp.p:
Oh, there's no use talking to you —
( crossing R.)
But I'll see you again, Mr. Graham.
( stopping in door, to GRAHAM)
You take my tip and don't do any business with that fellow until you find out who he is.
( exit around window )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: All that may have sounded queer to you, sir, but I'm not here to beat you out of your invention.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: There's nothing on earth my boy that could make me think you are —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Thank you —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: But five hundred dollars would have paid you for taking up my note — and I could have bought Betty a dress for the party but I'm sure you have done what is best —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Mr. Lockwood wants to see you over at the bank, father.
( begins cleaning up by the work bench )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, yes, he's got that note for you.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Oh, yes, that note. I'll go right over there. I never had so many things
happen to me in one day bfore in all my life
( exit )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( watches BETTY working a moment, then counts his stake again )
sp.p:
I might as well be broke as the way I am. Miss Graham!
( she comes down to him R.)
Could you get a party dress for thirty-two dollars?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Thirty-two dollars.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: And eighty cents.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Heavens I should think so.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Then go ahead.
(BETTY looks at him )
I'll stake you —
( offers her money )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Please do as a favor to me.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh, I couldn't take it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, you can.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No, I can't. Thank you ever so much just the same.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: But I want you to go to that party.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: You're awful kind — but I don't care to go now.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't care to? You insisted upon it a little while ago.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Yes, I know; but I've been thinking over what you said to me since then and I know I'd be out of place there — I belong here with father, working in the store.
( goes over to counter L. starting to work )
and I guess folks is better off if they stay where they belong —

div.stage: ( She glances at NAT, then returns to her work. She takes cloth and wipes counter . NAT stands R. C. watching her intently . TRACEY appears behind window coming from U. O. He beckons off L. and FOUR girls appear from C. one after the other and look at NAT through the window as TRACEY points him out to them. At the same time FOUR girls appear behind window U. R. from down R. JOSIE, ANGIE and ROLAND also appear at window R. C. and HI and WATTY appear at window up R. and look at NAT. During the time these people appear NAT has been watching BETTY but now turns up stage, sees crowd watching him, stops a moment in amazement, then grabs the broom which is at work bench R. and begins sweeping furiously .)
CURTAIN.

( 2nd CURTAIN. TRACEY, ANGIE, JOSIE and ROLAND still at the window . HI and WATTY in the doorway R. NAT and BETTY behind the counter . BETTY up stage and NAT down stage. The 8 girls swarming about the soda fountain, giggling and vainly asking for soda . NAT trying to wait on them all at once , BETTY trying to help him .) ( 3rd CURTAIN. Principals in a line down stage . NAT in the C. BETTY at his R. GRAHAM on his L. The eight girls up C. forming a second line .)

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: [Figure: 106KB

Same as ACT 2 — A month later. Tile flooring. Up R. is a large bay window with two chandeliers — three electric lights on each. In the window are large signs advertising different candies and medicines, etc. A large red and blue bottle ( usually used in drug store windows ). Also a red and blue stand light ( electric ) used to heighten the color of the bottles. Down R. is a double door leading into street, with brass handles. Up R. is Tabard Inn Library book case filled with books. The whole of the back wall is used for shelves filled with bottles of the usual prescription medicines and also various patent medicines and tooth powder, talcum powder, etc. A ladder against these shelves, one practical half filled bottle on shelf in reaching distance of ladder. Up L. is door leading into prescription room . L. is large and beautiful soda fountain and counter, a couple of electric stand lights on top of fountain and cards all around fountain advertising the different drinks, etc. On counter is rack filled with bottles, all filled with different flavors and several dishes with crushed fruit and a dish of eggs. Nice holders polished brightly and high stools all around counter. A counter up C. with cigar case with different cigars and cigarettes, etc. On top of case, a lighter. On R. of this counter is a display of various Mdse. in the center of counter a roll stand with two sizes of wrapping paper . C. and just below the counter is a little desk with telephone and telephone books and chair. Upper end of soda counter is a cash register. Several electric signs on center counter, another chair R. Center L. is a door with office painted on it in gold letters . 2 large arc lights hanging from the ceilings. Through window is seen same backing as Act II. Moonlight effect outside — lights in windows and in street lamps . AT RISE: — BOY is going over a lot of packages to be delivered . TRACEY is at the telephone .
(TRACEY is well dressed in this act .)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
No, mam. Mr. Duncan won't get here till after Thursday evenin' meetin' — 'bout twenty minutes. Oh, yes'm, he's allus at church if there's anythin' goin' on there. They're comin' right over. Boy's jest startin' with 'em. Yes 'em — g-bye!
( hangs up receiver. To Boy )
Got everything, Herman.

sp.speaker: HERMAN.
sp.p: Yep!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Take these packages to Miss Lyman's first; she's been telephonin' fer them. When you git 'em all delivered, go home an' go to bed. You want to git here by six in the mornin'.

sp.speaker: HERMAN.
sp.p:
I'll be here all right, all right! G'night!
( exits with arm full of packages )

div.stage: (TRACEY put a few things on the counter, straight. Goes up behind soda counter, takes off his white coat and puts on street coat .)
(ANGIE enters L. comes to C. TRACEY sees her .)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Hello!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Ready?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: No, Mr. Graham ain't back yet.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Guess I won't wait.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Aw why? He'll be here pretty quick.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Nat's at meetin' ain't he?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: A course!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Then, he'll come up by here takin' Josie Lockwood home.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: What if he will?

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: I don't want him to think I'm chasing after you!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
He won't.
( hesitating )
'Cause — 'cause he knows all about us!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Knows all about us!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yep!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: TRACE.
sp.p: I told him!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: You did? — Well, I —

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh, don't get mad, Angie. You see when he first came here, every one of you girls was always hangin' around after him.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Why Tracey Tanner!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh, yes, you wuz too. The hull crowd of you, an' you know it! An, I was afraid he might git stuck on you too, an' so — I asked him not to.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Well of all things!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I couldn't help it. You don't know how I felt.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Did you tell him how you felt?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yep! I didn't 'tend to, but he spoke so nice, and I was feelin' so strong that it all came out 'afore I thought.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What did you say to him?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I told him you was the best lookin' girl in town.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: The idea!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Well, by gosh, you are, all right! And
I told him please to let you alone and pick out anyone o' the others.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What'd he say?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: He said he guessed I was stuck on you.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: He did?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Well not them words, but that's what it meant.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What were the words?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: He said: "It strikes me, my boy, that you — Oh — you know."

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: No — what?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: "That you — love her."

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What did you say?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I said I did, but I didn't stand much chance, 'cause you was so swell an' I worked in Pa's Livery Stable and was fat!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Oh, Tracey!
( laughs )
What did he say to that?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: He says, "Nonsense, if you want her and will follow the rules I give you, it's a cinch."

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: I think it is all perfectly horrid!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Aw, please don't be mad; Angie. You see he was right. When I got dressed up like he told me and started goin' to your church regular, you began lettin' me come to see you for th' first time.

div.stage: ( There is a noise at the door . ANGIE springs away from TRACEY. SAM GRAHAM and SPERRY, the drummer, enter R. They have met at the door .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Nat got a note from you yesterday.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Yes, I wrote him I was coming. Never stayed over night here before.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Well, have a chair.
(SPERRY takes the chair )
I'm a little late, I guess, Tracey.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh, that's all right.

div.stage: (SPERRY crosses L. looks around . ANGIE crosses R. toward door .)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Why, hello, Angie. Goin' to see that Tracy gets home safe?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
No, she was passin' and I got her to wait for me.
( crossing R.)
We both go the same way and don't neither of us like walkin' alone.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: That's right, Tracey, that's the way to look at it.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
G'night.
( spoken together )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Good-night, Mr. Graham.
( spoken together )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Good-night. Better take a little candy with you, Tracey.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
I got some.
(TRACEY and ANGIE exit R.)

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Will Mr. Duncan get around again to-night?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, yes. This is prayer meeting night. It's the only night he lets me come here. He's so afraid I'll do too much work. I guess it disturbs his sleep!

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: The store looks different to you, don't it, Sam?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: The whole world looks different to me since he came. There's no one like that boy on this earth, sir, no one!

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
It was a fine thing for you to get him. How did he happen to come her?
( sitting L.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I don't know. Lord sent him, I reckon.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Then he's never told.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
No, and I've never asked him. He said once he was trying a new method for getting rich.
( sitting at counter )

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: He picked out a curious town to try it.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM
sp.p:
That's what I told him, but he said "It's the best kind of a place if you know the system?"
( becomes serious )
But he's wonderful, Sperry. He reduces the debt here every month; there isn't a more comfortable house in town than the one Nat rented and fixed up for us and he's sent Betty to a fine school —

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Sent your daughter to School?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Yes, she's been gone six months. Comes home for her first vacation to-morrow. You know Sperry —
( rising )
I feel toward Nat as I would toward a son, and no boy could be more devoted to a father than he is to me.

div.stage: ( The door R. opens and BETTY enters. She is dressed in a simple but very smart traveling costume and the contrast in her appearance from ACT II must be startling. She is pretty, shapely, and most attractive. Her manner shows her school training .)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Why, Betty, my little girl!
( they embrace )
We expected you to-morrow.
( takes grip from BETTY)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I found I could get here on the evening train and I just couldn't wait.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: This is Mr. Sperry, Betty.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: How de do, Mr. Sperry.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: How de do? I guess I used to see you around here, didn't I?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Yes — when I was the head clerk.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Well, you've — er — grown — since then. I congratulate you.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Well, I'll step over to the Radville House and get a room, and come back a little later and see Mr. Duncan. He'll know if there's anything you want, won't he?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, yes, he attends to all that.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: I'll run in to see you a moment in the morning. Good-night.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, do. Good-night.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Good-night, Mr. Sperry.

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
Good-night,
( exits R.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Well, well, well, my little Betty! My own little girl — My eyes but it's nice to have you home!
( holds her off at arm's length — and looks at her )
Why you look beautiful!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh! Father!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: You're just as pretty as a picture.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh, father!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, siree — you are! I can't hardly believe it — it's a wonderful change — wonderful!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Did I use to be very ugly before?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, no, no — but all this fixing up shows you off so well.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Yes, I know — it does make a difference, doesn't it? Where's Nat?
( looks around store )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: This is Thursday.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh, of course, prayer meeting?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Now, I know why you were so set on getting home to-night. I wasn't the magnet — it was Nat you wanted to see.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No — nonsense — I wanted to see you both.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: But, you want to see Nat very much?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Why, everyone wants to see their friends when they've been away, don't they?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, indeed! That's natural enough.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Certainly it is. And then Nat has helped us so!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: And you only want to see him on account of what he's done for us?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No — no — not only — that, but that's one reason.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: And the other reason is that you like him a little?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( trying to take it from a friendship point of view )
sp.p: I like him more than a little — I — I, oh, father!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: It's all right, Betty. It's all right. You can't like him — too much! He's honest and true and the more you care for him the better I shall be pleased!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Why — has — has — he spoken to you about me?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: He speaks of you nearly every day.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh, does he? But I mean — does he speak in a — a — what does he says about me?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, perhaps he'll tell you that himself.

div.stage: (TRACEY enters R. He comes in scowling but as he catches sight of BETTY, his expression changes to one of open-eyed wonder .)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: How do you do, Tracey? I'm glad to see you.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Gosh! How'd you do it?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Do what?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
I dunno, but you look great!
( shakes hands )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Thank you, Tracey, I'm glad you think so.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I thought you'd quit for the night, Tracey.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( his troubles coming back to him. Crosses to counter L.)
sp.p: So I had! But Angie just heard Betty was here and made me come down to see if you wanted me to work to-night.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, that was thoughtful now, very thoughtful. Have you had supper, Betty?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No, but I'm not a bit hungry really.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, but you must have your supper! Come right over to the house and Miss Carpenter'll get you something.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: All right, if you say so. How perfectly splendid the store looks Tracey, doesn't it?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You bet! And wait'll you see the house!

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: You'd hardly know the place, since Nat fixed it up. I declare I can't realize you're here!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
You will in time.
( coming down )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Well, come along. If you don't have supper before Nat gets home, you won't eat any at all.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Tell Mr. Duncan I'm gone. Won't you Tracey?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh, sure!

div.stage: ( Enter JOSIE LOCKWOOD and ROLAND BARNETT.)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
How do you do, Josie?
(JOSIE looks at BETTY in astonishment )
Good evening, Mr. Barnett!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Why, if it ain't Betty Graham!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: How'd do!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Well school ain't done you any harm!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I didn't expect it would. How have you been, Josie?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Real well, thanks. When did you get back?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I've just come from the station.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Did you come from the train alone?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Yes. Nat didn't know I was coming.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Then you haven't see him yet?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Not yet. Perhaps he's at the house now. Come along, father. We'll go and see. Good-night, good-night, Tracey.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
G'night!
( nearly together )

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p:
G'night!
( nearly together )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
So long!
( nearly together )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Good-night!
(BETTY and GRAHAM exit )

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: A pack of sweets, Tracey. What do you think of Betty Graham bein' rigged up like that?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: She looks out of place in it. That's the trouble of dressing up girls that aren't used to it.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I wonder if Nat Duncan will believe that?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: It will probably please him!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Sure it will! Because he likes her pretty well!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: It's no such thing! She looked so horrid he didn't like to have her around the store and so he sent her away to have her taught something.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.stage: ( seeing that he has gone too far )
sp.p:
Tracey, we want some soda.
( going toward counter )

div.stage: ( The door of the Conversation Parlor opens a little and NAT'S head shows for a moment in the doorway, then goes back .)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: What flavor, Josie?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Didn't Mr. Duncan come over here from meeting?
(ROLAND glances angrily at her, crossing at C.)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Nope!

div.stage: (NAT'S head disappears and door closes quietly .)

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Is he at the house?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I don't believe so.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: What do you care where he is?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I don't. But I can ask if I want to, can't I? I wanted to speak to him about choir rehearsal, that's all.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: What flavor did you say?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I don't think I want any! I've got a headache!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Oh, come on!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: No, I don't care for any, honestly — I'm going home!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Goin' to stop at Sam Graham's?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: No, I'm not — I don't feel well — and I'm going home .

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I'll go with you.

div.stage: (TRACEY turns up L. busies himself with putting articles in show cases .)

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, no, don't trouble. I know the way.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: What's the matter, Josie? I used to see you home Thursday nights always, but somehow I never do now. I haven't since Nat — well, not for a long time. Why is it?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I'm sure I don't know.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: You've no objections?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Why no, certainly not!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Well, then come on.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.stage: ( as ROLAND opens the door for her )
sp.p: I don't want to take you out of your way.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p:
Never you mind about that!
( exit ROLAND and JOSIE R.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Are you quite alone, Tracey?

div.stage: ( During the following scene , NAT must play so that it is quite clear that he is not in earnest .)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Where did you come from?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Through the back window.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
You jest missed seein' Josie.
( going down L. looking at door )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Heavens! What a blow!

div.stage: (NAT begins a busy inspection of stock, making notes of articles needed on shelves and in showcases, during scene .)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( watches NAT keenly a moment, in deep thought )
sp.p: Say, Nat did you sneak in that way because Roland was takin' Josie home?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, Tracey, it was because he wasn't taking her home.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yes, he was too, and is yet.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You don't tell me.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Yep! But —
( confidentially and reassuringly )
that needn't upset you none!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Thank you for those words. You're a true friend!
( going through door behind counter L.)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You ain't a foolin' me, are you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Why should I?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You're so cur'us. I don't never know when you mean what you're sayin' or not.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, don't say that.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I ain't the only one says it. Everybody in town says they don't understand you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( impressively, laying hand on TRACEY'S shoulder )
sp.p: Tracey, nothing in life is harder to bear than not being understood.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Then why the hell don't you talk so folks'll know what it's about?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Because — because Tracey I'm living here according to rules.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Say Nat, you treated me somethin' great once.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I haven't treated anybody since I've been here. I'm on the wagon.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I mean when I told you about me and Angie.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh! It's working, is it?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yep! Workin' immense! And I'd like to help you the same way if I could.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You would?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You're right, I would! And perhaps I can tell you something that will.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Speak, I beg!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You — er — you're tryin' to court Josie Lockwood, ain't ye?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well that's a secret, Tracey!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: All right, only if you are, she's yourn.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Just how do you figure that out?
( turning and looking at TRACEY)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh, I could tell to-night when she was in here with Roland, she was a lookin' for you and when she seen you wasn't here, she wouldn't wait for no soda nor nothin'. Said she was feelin' awful for no soda nor nothin'. Said she was feelin' awful and going home. Roland went with her but she didn't want him to.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Harry's right. There's nothing to it.
( writing )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Who's Harry?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: A friend of mine. Tracey you want to get married, don't you?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Gosh! I should smile! But I can't afford it yet.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It's a contrary world, Tracey. A contrary world.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Why? Don't you want to?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well no, I don't think I do.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Well you don't have to if you don't want to, do you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, if the girl asks me I've got to.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Aw you're foolin'. Oh, say, Betty's home.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Betty!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yep, on the six-fifty. She's over to the house having supper. That's why I'm working to-night, so's you and Mr. Graham needn't stay.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Why, this is one of your Angie — evenings, isn't it?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yes, but you'll want to see Betty won't you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, there'll be time enough for that after I close up. Go ahead and keep your date.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Can I?
( taking book from NAT, and getting hat through door behind counter )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Certainly, run along. Take Angie over to see Betty.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Thanks.
( starts for door R.)
If Angie asks you about it, tell her you said I could go, will ye?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, I'll tell her. Remember what I told you now. Don't make love too much, let her do that.

div.stage: (TRACEY stops at door .)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: That's the hardest rule of all for me. G'night.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Good night.
(TRACEY exits R. Phone bell rings — Listening to bell )
Oh, Lord, Josie.
( he goes to phone, takes receiver and speaks with imitation of TRACEY'S voice )
Hello! Yep, he's here but he's turrible busy, who's this? Who? Josie Lockwood. Oh, all right, sure, he'll speak to you . Wait a minute.
( he pauses long enough to have it appear that he has been called to the phone, then speaks in natural voice pleasantly )
Hello! Hello! Josie — what? Why I came right over here from church. Yes, I know you were — with Roland — Tracey told me. Because you were talking to him, so I didn't wait. Well I couldn't know that could I? How? I say how could I tell you didn't prefer to have him see you
home?
( makes a wry face, as if it were an effort to say it )
No, I can't possibly to-night. I'm all alone here. What? Oh, no, he isn't. I just sent him home — yes — no, that isn't the reason. I know she is, but I haven't seen her yet. No, I haven't, really.
( as if speaking to some one in the store )
Good evening sir — I'll attend to you in just a minute — pardon me —
( into phone )
What did you say? Oh well, yes, rather busy, yes all right, good bye.

div.stage: ( Hangs up phone and shakes his fist at it — then goes L. Enter HARRY KELLOGG R. He stands just inside the door, looking at NAT. NAT is dumfounded .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well! Old Doctor Duncan!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Harry!
( rushes to him and grabs him. They embrace each other and slap each other on back )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Nat!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What the devil are you doing here?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Business and other things.
( shaking hands violently )
Well old fellow, how are you

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Sh — h — listen, I'm a business man! Pipe my store.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Gad, I'm blowed, if it ain't true! I couldn't believe half your letters. Who could?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Who could? Ask any of the natives. Ask Blinky Lockwood who owns the whole country.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: He's to be your father-in-law and might be prejudiced. By the way, I've got to see him to-night.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: See Blinky! You never told me you knew him.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
I don't. This is for the firm, we are going to do some business for him. He wired me to come to the house, but I shan't stay there — after
I've seen him I'll come back here and go to the hotel. I'm going to hang around here a couple of days with you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Good! But none of that hotel stuff. I'll put you up. Do it in style too.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, how is my scheme coming on? Are you carrying out all the rules according to agreement?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Every rule. Not a drink, not a smoke and not a swear, and the church thing — well I own it, that's all.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Bully for you! Well? Was I right?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I should say you were! It's so easy it seems a shame to do it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( up L. C. sitting on telephone desk )
sp.p: Good! I knew it. And you made a play for Lockwood's daughter, eh?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Certainly not! You're forgetting your instructions. I allowed her to make a play for me.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Of course. My mistake — how far has it gone? Has she won you yet? Are you engaged?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
No, I've got two months yet.
( going R. to book case )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: So you have There's no hurry. Let her take her time.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It's worse than that. It's got to a place where I have to dodge her now.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Splendid. Only don't carry the dodging too far.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Do you really want me to carry out the rest of the agreement?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Most certainly I do. Why not?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, when you proposed the scheme I was down and three times out, and willing to take a chance at anything, no matter how contemptible. Now it's different.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Good Heavens! You don't mean you'd be willing to live here.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I don't know. I think I'm beginning to like it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Spend your life here with nobody around you but a bunch of rubes, slaving away in this measly store.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Hold on now, don't you call this a "measly store." There ain't a finer drug store in the State.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Is it possible that this is Nat Duncan? The fellow who hated work and couldn't earn a living. Gad, I've arrived just in time.
( moving L.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: In time for what?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: To set you straight. Here's the heiress you came to get, ready and anxious; everything coming your way and you're half inclined to back out.

div.stage: (HARRY sits on chair L. of desk with back to desk, and NAT on desk behind him .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
See here, Harry, when I first landed here I had about as gay and sociable a time as a bell buoy in the ocean.
(HARRY laughs )
I nearly died for something to do and someone to talk to. Then I got in with this old Prince Graham, and for the first time in my life I was glad to work, to take my mind off the dullness. There was next to nothing in this store — and Graham and his daughter hadn't a penny. It was so peculiar finding someone that was worse off than I was that I used up all the coin you advanced me straightening them out.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, you wrote me about that.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Then I got dead interested trying to make the store amount to something and I never was so happy in my life, as when it began to show a profit. I realized things were easier for the old man and I found by scrimping a little we could send the girl to school. She was well worth it you know and —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Oho! So that's the idea.
( rising and going down a bit )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
No — no — no — not at all. Only she — well, she's a nice little girl, Harry, just needed a chance in life, that's all.
( slight pause )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, since I've been working here — I've stuck to all the terms of our agreement. Singled out this Lockwood girl and worked all the degrees. Didn't say much, no love-making but let her catch me looking sadly at her once in a while.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: That's the way!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, that' the way. But the longer I keep it up, the meaner I feel. I'm getting along on my own account now and —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: And you want to back out?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I want you to agree to let me out. These rubes, as you call them struck me as being nothing but a lot of jay freaks at first, but when you get to know them they are just as human as city people. I like 'em now and on the level I'm getting kind of stuck on church. And as for work , why I eat it up.
(NAT turns )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Nat, my poor crazy friend, listen to me. This working and helping Graham is all very noble and fine and I'm glad you've done it, this drug store is a monument to your business ability; but come on down to earth now. This place is paying a little profit, very good, that's all it will ever do. It's all new to you and you're having the time of your life finding out you're good for something. But, from now it will get stale; and before long you'll hate it and next you'll hate the town , and then you'll be right where you were before. Now I'm going to hold you to your bargain for your own sake.
( goes to NAT)
If you're stuck on the town and the store you can keep right on just as well after you are married, but if you're not — you've got a fortune to do what you like with. Ah, don't — don't let this chance slip now on your life!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: But think of the injustice to the girl! From the way I've been living, she thinks I'm closely related to the Saints.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Well, if you think you are taking a mean advantage on that account — when she proposes to you, tell her everything about yourself. Just the sort of chap you've been; and if she wants to back out, I will have nothing to say.
( crosses L. turns up stage )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, a bargain's a bargain. I gave you my word of honor I'd go through with this thing and I'll stick to it, but I tell you now, I don't like it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, I know that's the way you feel now but sometimes you'll come to me and say, "Harry if you'd let me back out of that agreement. I'd never have forgiven you."

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: All right! I suppose you know best.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
You can bet I do! Now I'll go and see the man who's making money for you.
( crosses R. to door )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh say, how is that patent burner getting on?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Our lawyers are still working on it. The Modern Gas Co. seems like a big thing. They've got a burner that does the trick all night, but if we find out it's an infringement on Graham's patent, we'll put a crimp in them. How much of it do you own?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It's all Mr. Graham's.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
All Graham's, and you wrote me as if it was everything in the world to you?
( going to NAT)
You're still far from a business man Nat.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I suppose so.
( enter JOSIE R. NAT continues quickly )
Why, good evening, may I present my friend, Mr. Kellogg?
(HARRY crosses to JOSIE)

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Pleased to meet you, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Charmed! Is this Miss Josephine Lockwood?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes. THE Miss Lockwood?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I've heard of you, Miss Lockwood.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Is that so?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes. I'm on my way to your house now to meet your father.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh yes, Mr. Kellogg, of course; he's waiting for you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Is he? Well I'll soon put a stop to that.
( going to door )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Do you know the way?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, thanks, the house was pointed out to me. I'll see you later Nat. I hope I may see you before I leave Miss Lockwood.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Thanks, I hope so.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Hurry back.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I will Good evening.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Good evening.

div.stage: ( Exit HARRY.)

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Did you know Mr. Kellogg in New York?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Yes, New York and other places. What are you doing down town? I thought you were ill!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Aren't you glad to see me?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
You should know I am, but it's unexpected.
( goes up R.)

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I came down town because I just had to ask you something.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Why did you run away from the meeting? Why didn't you walk home with me?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( trying to act as if he were hurt )
sp.p: I told you over the phone.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, how silly you are.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: We are all silly — on certain occasions —

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: You don't really think I wanted Roland Barnett to take me home, do you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It seemed so, but that's all right — why shouldn't you?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Must I tell you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh no, please don't.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
I see that I must. You are so blind, it was because I wanted to be with you . There —
( going down L. C.)
Now I've said it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( in the hope of changing the subject following her down )
sp.p:
Oh, but you don't mean it — I know you don't. You're saying that because you have such a tender heart, and don't want to hurt me — you —
( he stops half suspecting what is coming .)

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Nat, would it make you happy if you knew I meant it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looks around and then at her uncertainly )
sp.p: Well, what do you think?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Then please believe me when I say it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh no don't say it.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: You know I like you. It's awfully hard for me, Nat, to have folks think that I'm pursuing you and that you are trying to avoid me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Josie!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Well, that's the way it looks. You don't want it to appear that way, do you?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Of course I don't.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Then — then why don't you stop it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I can't.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: If you liked me as well as I like you, you would —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Ah, child, you don't know what you're saying.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Yes, I do.
(NAT stops suddenly and looks at her )
I don't believe you care anything about me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh Josie, please.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Well, you've never told me so.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Don't you see that I shouldn't. Why, just think! You are an only daughter — an only daughter.
( tears in voice )
Not only your father's only daughter, but your mother's only daughter. Your father is my friend. How unfair, it would be to him.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: O pap wants you to, he told me so.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
But listen, Josie; you are rich, an heiress, I am a poor man. Would you want it said that I was after your money?
( gonig to her )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: No one would dare even think such a thing.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh yes, they would, you don't know the world as I do. And, for all you know they might be right. How could you tell that —

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, don't say such horrid things, I could tell. A woman always can. I know you'd be incapable of such a thing. Papa knows it too. No one has ever got ahead of papa, and he says you are a fine, steady, Christian man and he would rather see me your wife than anyone he knows.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
This is so sudden.
( goes up R. of desk and then turns )
Josie, the time has come — you must know the truth!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh, Nat!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I am not what you think me.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Oh, Nat!
( moving toward him )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Nor what your father thinks me!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
OH NAT!
( goes back a step )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Nor what anyone in this town thinks me. Oh, Nat — excuse me — I wanted to save you from saying it again. I am not a Christian — it's all a bluff — I didn't know anything about a church until I came here. I smoke and I drink and I swear, and I gamble; and I cut them out just to trick you into caring for me —

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I don't believe it!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Ah alas, Josie! It's true, only too true.
( he buries his face in his hands )

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Nevertheless, Nat. I will be your wife!
( going to him, puts her arms around his neck )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( suddenly looking up in great alarm )
sp.p: Josie!

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Nat — my —

div.stage: (NAT drops his head on her shoulder in despair .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( with change of manner and real seriousness )
sp.p: Josie — I'll try to make you a good husband — and that wasn't in the agreement.

div.stage: (PETER WILLING enters R. staggering. He is somewhat intoxicated and has a bad cut on his forehead .)

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
'Scuse me. Kin I see you a minute, Doc?
( goes R. and sits weakly in front of counter R. C.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Hello, Pete, what's happened to you?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
Perhaps I'd better go.
( getting between door and PETE)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I can't leave the store just now — if you'll wait —

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
I don't mind going alone one bit.
( frightened look at PETE)
I'll telephone you later —
( very low tone )
Good night, dearest, I'm so happy.
( she kisses him and exits quickly R.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( stands a moment looking after her; shakes his head and turns to PETER)
sp.p:
Well, Pete, let's have a look.
( pulls PETE'S hand away from forehead )
Great Scott! That's a bird, who hit you?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Wife.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looks again where JOSIE went off and shivers )
sp.p:
Wife, eh?
( goes out of door U. L. for bowl )
Well she certainly gave it to you good.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: She'll kill me some day.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( still collecting remedies for PETE, goes behind counter. Gets cotton and adhesive plaster, etc. )
sp.p: Oh, don' say that.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Yes, she will — sure! But I'd about as soon be dead as to live with her.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
You'd been drinking again, hadn't you?
( going up ladder up C. to get carbolic )

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Yes, but she drove me to it. Mr. Duncan, you ain't got no idea how lucky you be that ye ain't married.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Is that so?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: No idee at all. And I hope you won't never have.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: But I'm going to be married, Pete.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Oh, no. Don't Mr. Duncan! Don't you never do it! You take warnin' by me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: But I'm engaged.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Then break it off, for God's sake, break it off — now — before it's too late. Do anything rather than that — drink — lie — steal — murder — commit suicide. I don't care what — only — keep single!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
But suppose you get a lot of money by marrying?
( down to desk, preparing bandage )

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
No matter how much you get, it ain't enough!
( turns front )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
I'm inclined to think you're about right, Pete.
( bathing wound )

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: You bet I'm right. I'm married and I know!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
There, that's better. Now go home and let me see you sober in the morning.
( puts bandages, etc., away )

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: I ain't going home to-night.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You've got to get some sleep. That's the only way you can straigthen up.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Well, I'll go over to the barn and sleep with the horse.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Won't he step on you?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Maybe, but I'd rather risk him than my wife.

div.stage: (ROLAND enters R. He is in a rage. Stops on seeing NAT and PETE.)

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Say, I want to see you —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, go ahead and have a good look!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Don't try to be funny or you may get hurt.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: What d'ye mean by that?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That's all right, Pete. Don't get nervous, Rolly won't hurt anybody.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Now don't you —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Ah! Ah! Ah! Careful! Be a good boy now!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Do you think —

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Here you —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Let him alone —
( leads PETE toward the door )

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: I ain't afraid of him.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Neither am I.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
I can lick anybody in town — except my wife.
( exits R. NAT, turns to ROLAND and there is a short pause )

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Now see here, me and you's apt to have trouble.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh, really, who'll start it?

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I'll start it and start it damn quick if you don't leave Josie Lockwood alone.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You don't tell me!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Yes, I do tell ye. Ye got her to come back here again tonight after I took her home from meetin'. From now on I want you to let her alone, and you'll do it too if you know what's beet for yourself.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What do you mean by this line of talk?

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I'll tell you what I mean. I was a-goin' with Josie Lockwood steady for more'n a year before you came here and you thought on account of her money you'd sneak in and cut me out.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Was her money the reason you were after her.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p:
N — no, and 'tain't no business of yours if it were. But here's what I'm gettin' at.
( slowly and impressively )
A cashier skipped out of the New York National Bank about ten months ago. And they ain't got no track of him yet.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p:
I've had my suspicious all along but the other day I got a description of him and the description just fits — want to see it —
( holding paper toward NAT)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Fits what —

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Oh don't you try to be so darned innocent, you can't fool me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: So you think I was that bank fellow, eh?

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: You keep away from Josie or you'll find out what I think. Why if I was to show this to Mr. Lockwood.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That will do for this evening, thanks.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Are you goin' to quit chasin' after her?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'll begin chasing after you, if you don't get out of here!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: You better agree —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( grabbing ROLAND by the coat collar and pushing him quickly out of door R. After he has thrown ROLAND out he picks up his hat and holds it out to him )
sp.p: Here's your hat.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Throw it out here.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Come in again any time when you want to apologize.
( the phone bell rings . NAT goes to it and takes down receiver )
Eh hello, Josie — what — that's right, but I'm not used to it yet you know — let me try again. Now ready?
( sweetly )
Hello, oh hello darling! How's that? Told your father. Told him what? About the engagement.
( hopefully )
Was he angry?
( resignedly )
Oh he wasn't, eh? What did he say?
( listlessly )
Wasn't that nice of him?
( door opens and BETTY enters . NAT turns and sees her — He doesn't know her at first. To BETTY)
Just a moment please — why if it isn't Betty.
( hangs up receiver quickly and goes to BETTY and takes both her hands )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Nat!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Hanged if I knew you at first!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
I tried to wait until closing time but I just couldn't do it!
(NAT begins to comprehend the great change in her and the feeling grows as she continues speaking )
I didn't send word. I was coming to-night, I wanted to surprise you — all of you!
(NAT is still staring )
Tracey told you I was here, didn't he?
( noticing NAT'S stare )
Why what is the matter?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( pulling himself together with an effort )
sp.p:
Why I —
( short laugh )
Gad! You nearly took my breath away! I — I can hardly believe it.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Believe what?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That you are little Betty Graham. I never saw such a change.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
It's a change for the better, isn't it, Nat?
( crossing over L.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I should think it was! It's marvelous Betty.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Did I use to be so awful then?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Awful! Nonsense, you know you weren't only, now —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( her voice a little unsteady with great gratitude )
sp.p:
Does it make you a little proud?
( sitting down at soda counter )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: To know you've done it all?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Rot! You did it yourself.
( comes over and sits half facing her )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Oh no! Why Nat, you began it the first day I saw you in the old store, by the things you said to me. Then I watched you as you made life a heaven for father and me; and I thought, if I were a man I'd try to be as near like you as I could. The time you told me you were going to send me to school, I said to myself, "I'll follow his example just as near as I possibly can — I'll work ever so hard and I'll try to treat people as he treats them, and, oh, Nat, it's worked so wonderfully! It's made all the girls at school like me, and now , what's ten thousand times best of all, you notice an improvement the moment you see me! And I, I never was so happy in my life.
(BETTY caresses his hand, which she has held through this speech )
Nat, you are the very best man in the whole world!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't — don't for Heaven's sake!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: I know you don't like me to tell you this, but I am going to just the same. Why father and I both cried when he showed me how you'd fixed up the house.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Is it as bad as that?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh Nat, don't. You must let me tell you the truth about yourself. It's splendid to live the life you do. You are all unconscious of it and I want you to realize it? It makes everybody love you —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
That's right! That was the idea —
(BETTY looks at him surprised. There is a pause )
Betty does it make you — er — feel that way toward me?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Why of course — everyone who —
( stops suddenly and turns away embarrassed )
Oh Nat.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
That's why I came here Betty!
(BETTY still turned away and not understanding . NAT is facing front and now looks down )
Yes, I — came here with the idea of getting married —
(BETTY takes a deep breath and waits, her hands clasped — her head up )
You never guessed that did you?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, it's the truth, and I can't tell you now — not now —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
No, Nat dear not now.
( happily )
I — think I'd better go home — I —
( getting up and going R.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( looking suddenly at her, realizing she doesn't understand )
sp.p:
Wait, Betty — I must tell you — I must .
( she stops C. she stands motionless, expecting he will tell her he loves her )
To-night I — to-night — I became engaged to Josie Lockwood.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( stands paralyzed, but not a muscle of her face changes. There is a long pause. When she speaks her voice is perfectly steady and sweet )
sp.p: Oh Nat dear, I'm so glad for you. I wish you all the happiness in the world. Good night!

div.stage: ( With a set smile she goes slowly to the door and exits quietly and naturally, without showing a trace of emotion. When she is gone , NAT, after a pause looks toward door, speaks between his teeth .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Blithering fool! Why didn't I know I loved her like this?
( springing up behind soda counter )
Well, the rules are off! I can have a drink — I can have a million drinks — .if I want them.
( gets bottle of whiskey from counter, pours out big drink, takes a swallow, makes a wry face, sets glass glass down )
Ugh! I've lost my taste for it! I can have a smoke. That'll help a little.
( goes to cigar counter, takes cigar, lights it, crosses to C. takes two puffs, throws it away )
I've got so I don't like 'em any more. Oh I'll be — I'll be — God help me I've forgotten how to swear.

div.stage: (SPERRY enters R.)

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Good evening, Mr. Duncan. How are you to-night?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Rotten!
( going L.)

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Dear me! What's the trouble?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Long story.
( going up to cigar counter getting hat )

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p: Perhaps you'd rather not see me to-night.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: SPERRY.
sp.p:
I'm sorry — good evening.
( starts for door )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Heard about you at the Lockwood's Nat.
( offering hand )
Let me con —

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Keep away from me! Keep away I tell you! You and your confounded systems have got me into all this —
( starts towards door )

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What's the matter with you? Here hold on — where are you going?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: To the only place I can get consolation.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'm going back to church!

div.stage: ( He exits R. HARRY and SPERRY stand in amazement looking after him .)
CURTAIN.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: [Figure: 90KB
House and grounds of SAM GRAHAM'S Home .

( House D. R. with door and steps facing C. windows upstairs and down stairs all having curtains and shades. Veranda all the way round house. Trailing vines on porch. Light streaming from window R. onto porch. Hat rack with hat and coat and umbrella just inside of door. The back drop shows undulating country, with river, and several houses setting on hills in the distance. Large tree directly in the C. Rose bush L. C. Summer house up L. with bench all round on the inside. A rose bush R. and another L. of summer house. Hammock swinging on a frame down L. Bench at side of porch . TIME. — About 9 o'clock at night and effects show gathering of storm. Foliage borders overhead. Wood wings, ground cloth is green with a gray path leading from Porch to L. and down stage a strip of rubber tarpaulin for catching the rain. At first border rain pipes, etc. Borders blue at rise. Olivet floods in all the entrances. White foots one third up, at rise. Baby spot on each side in First Entrance . Same evening as ACT III . DISCOVERED. — BETTTY and ANGIE sitting on the porch . TRACEY enters hurriedly up L. Crosses to girls .

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( rushing on excitedly from L. to R.)
sp.p: What do you think, Nat and Josie's just got engaged!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yep.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Nat let me off just now to go and call on you and they told me at the house you were over here with Betty and as I came back by the store I saw a strange man in there all alone and he told me that Nat had just got engaged and left him there so I locked up.
(BETTY gets up, starts into house, stops when ANGIE speaks to her )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: I don't believe it. Did you know about it, Betty?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Yes, Nat just told me.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Wasn't you surprised most to death?
( leaning against porch post )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Er — yes — I was —

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Ah, I knew it was comin' —
( sitting down on steps )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: You did?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Yes, certainly I did —
( very proudly )
'Twas me fixed it up.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Ah — ha! I told him to-night Josie was after him and as soon's he found it out he got engaged to her. Didn't waste no time about, did he?
( looking at BETTY and ANGIE)

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Gee! I wish I could get it over's quick as that.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Tracey!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
That's right, Tracey — why don't you try? I'll go in and give you a chance.
( goes to door )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh no — don't go.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Yes, I will!

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Please don't go.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
But I want to see Father.
( she exits into house )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Gee, I'm glad she's gone.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What made you say that before her?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: I didn't mean to. I was thinkin' it and it slipped out.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: It was perfectly terrible.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Was it?
( goes over to the hammock )
Come on over in the hammock.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Aw why? They'll be comin' out here on the stoop.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What if they do?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Well —
( hesitates )
— we can't get engaged with folks hangin' around, kin we?

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: The idea. I don't want to get engaged.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You said you would last night.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: But I said not for ever so long.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Well, if's to-night now. That's ever so long enough for me. Aw come on over in the hammock.
( goes over toward hammock )
I want to be engaged now. You ought to let me have my way about somethin'.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
If you talk like that I'm going!
( she goes down on lawn in front of hammock )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh look!

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
What?
( stops in front of hammock )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Here's the hammock.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Oh no — we mustn't —
( lookng to sky up stage )
Look, it's going to rain.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( seating her into the hammock, sits beside her )
sp.p:
Then let's hurry — we ain't got much time.
( swings hammock gently )

div.stage: (ROLAND comes around above the house up C. quickly )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh shucks!

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.stage: ( starts to house when he sees TRACEY)
sp.p: Is that you Tracey?
