sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Yep! One of us is me —

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Well go and tell Nat Duncan I want to see him.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Tell him yourself — can't you see I'm busy?

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p:
You young —
( he starts to porch )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: He ain't in the house.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p:
Where is he?
( stops with one foot on bottom step )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Over callin' on his financee.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Josie Lockwood and him is engaged — That's what — I always knowed he'd cut you out.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.stage: ( wildly crossing L. behind TRACEY and flourishing a paper )
sp.p:
He'll never marry her. I'll tell you that. I've got proof of what Nat Duncan is here — and I'm going to show it to Mr. Lockwood right now.
( exits quickly )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: What do you suppose he means?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Oh he's crazy — don't pay any attention to him. He's gone — that's all I care.
( they swing again . TRACEY puts his arm around her )
Say Angie when you heard Nat and Josie were engaged didn't it make you feel kind a — lonesome?
(ANGIE nods "yes" )
It did me. Now we —

div.stage: (PETE WILLING comes on from U. R.)

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
Excuse me.
( goes down C.)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Oh shucks. Here comes another.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
I want to see Mr. —
( seeing TRACEY and ANGIE in hammock and crossing to L. to hammock )
Oh Tracey, 'tain't true Mr. Duncan's getting married, is it?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: No — but he's engaged. That's the next best thing.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: The next worst thing, but I just heard he was gettin' married, to-night. 'Tain't so, is it?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
Then there's time yet. I'm a-goin' to save him. He's the best friend I've got and I made up my mind to kill him sooner than see him married.
( puts his hand into his hip pocket as if getting out pistol . ANGIE holds on to TRACEY. TRACEY puts his arms protectingly around her and PETE pulls out his handkerchief and wipes his forehead )
But engagements kin be broke, thank God!
( moves R.)

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: You must be crazy I guess.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: No I ain't. I was once but I got sense now it's too late.

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Why Pete, don't you believe in gettin' married?

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p:
Not for a man, I don't.
( eyeing them an instant )
Here, don't you go gettin' Tracey there to marry you. He's too nice a little fellow. If you care anythin' about him show it by makin' him keep single.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( getting out of hammock and going toward PETE)
sp.p: Here, you git away from here.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Oh all right! Just for getting sassy I hope you'll have to marry her.

div.stage: ( Exits L. At PETE'S exit, enter GRAHAM from house )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p: Go on now.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: What's the matter, Tracey? You're not fighting with Angie, are you?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.stage: ( going back into hammock, sits R. of ANGIE)
sp.p: No — ain't even had a chance to talk to her, everybody keeps comin' around jest at the wrong time.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Well — I don't see anything to disturb you now — if I get out of your way —
( turning to go into the house )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p: Oh no, don't Mr. Graham. We must go any way.

div.stage: ( Enter up R. KELLOGG.)

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: I beg pardon but is this where Mr. Duncan lives?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
That settles it — come on, Angie.
( starts around hammock with ANGIE and starting off L.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: He'll be here soon I expect. Going, Tracey?

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
Yep. It's time Angie was gittin' home. Good night.
( getting hat out of hammock )

sp.speaker: ANGIE.
sp.p:
Good night.
( together )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Good night — come again.
( together )

sp.speaker: TRACEY.
sp.p:
We will —
( to ANGIE)
Sometime when everybody ain't lookin' for Nat.
( they exit L.)

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Are you Mr. Graham?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Yes sir!
( on porch )

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Then I've got some news for you.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
For me?
( down off steps )

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Yes, and I'd like to talk it over with you before Nat comes. My name is Kellogg.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Kellogg! Not Henry Kellogg — Nat's friend?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Yes, I'm the fellow.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Well, well, well! I'm real glad to see you. Sit right down. Do! My what a surprise this will be for Nat!
( going toward porch and calling )
Betty!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: There's some one out here you'll be glad to see!

div.stage: ( Smiles and motions HARRY not to give it away .)

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Your little girl?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Yes, sir, just home from school.
(BETTY opens door — comes quickly on to porch — stops suddenly at steps upon seeing a stranger )
Who do you suppose this is?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( looking at HARRY — with a little laugh )
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Nat's old friend — Mr. Kellogg!

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Oh!
( comes quickly down steps and shakes hands cordially )
How do you do Mr. Kellogg?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p:
So you're the little girl.
(GRAHAM nods "yes" )

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Have you seen Nat?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Yes, he just left me.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh! How delighted he must have been.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: You'd have thought so if you'd heard what he said to me.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: In church.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Church? Why did he go back there?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: By jove, I think I've just found out.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Oh you've heard —
( trying to keep her voice steady )
That — that Nat is engaged to be married?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p:
Yes, I've heard it.
( there is a moment's pause )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( trying to be cheerful about it — and looking uneasily at BETTY)
sp.p: It was quite a surprise to us — He must have decided very suddenly.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: No — he had the idea when he came here.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: It'll seem queer without him at the store.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.stage: ( looking curiously at the old man and BETTY)
sp.p: Yes, you won't care to lose him, I suppose?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Nat is very dear to Father and me, Mr. Kellogg, and we'll be glad of anything that will make him happy —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( who is near BETTY, puts his arm about her and holds her a moment, then tries to change the subject )
sp.p: Better ask Miss Carpenter if the spare room's ready, Betty?

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.stage: ( before HARRY can interrupt, goes up steps onto porch )
sp.p:
Oh yes —
( to HARRY)
and I'll get you and Nat some supper,
( in doorway )

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Please don't trouble.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
It isn't any trouble — ifs fun.
( she goes into house quickly )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.stage: ( he takes a step toward porch to make sure BETTY is out of hearing )
sp.p: I thought I wouldn't talk about the engagement before her for a while. You see Nat's been so much to us that it's sort of a shock just at first —

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p:
I understand — and I won't mention it again.
( crossing down R.)

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Thank you —
( cheerful tone again )
I believe you said you had something to tell me before Nat came —

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p:
Oh yes — quite an important business matter —
( sitting on lower end of steps )

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Business? Oh then you'd better wait 'till he-comes.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I guess you know why. Nat's often told me of your wonderful success in Wall Street and I've always felt what a great help he must have been to you. It must have been very hard for you to get on without him to advise you —

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Are you talking about Nat?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Why yes —

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p:
Well, I've managed somehow.
But Nat tells me this matter is entirely your affair —
( taking telegram from his pocket )
Here's a telegram I just received to-night from our attorneys.
( reading )
Modern Gas Company offer fifty thousand dollars and ten thousand shares stock for Graham patent. Advise us"
(GRAHAM looks up front thoughtfully )
I consider that a very fair offer —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Fifty thousand dollars. He's a wonderful boy — wonderful!

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Well, what do you think?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: About accepting this proposition —

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Oh, that's just as he says.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Just as he says, but I understand Nat owns no part of this patent.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: He owns it all.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: What! But he told me it was all yours.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: Yes, of course he did, that's just like him.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: But what ararngement did you have?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: We didn't have any.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Then why in Heaven's name do you say it's all Nat's?

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Well, I'll tell you. Suppose you were an old man, Mr. Kellogg, who'd failed at everything you'd undertaken — suppose you had a little motherless girl that you loved but because of your inability she went about so shabby and forlorn that all the young folks laughed at her and wouldn't have anything to do with her. Suppose you'd come to the end and were about to be turned out of your store when along comes a young fellow and gave you every dollar he had in the world to start you over again and then he worked with all his might — day after day until he'd made everything comfortable and easy for you, suppose he changed your shabby little girl into
a beautiful young woman and then a patent that you'd have sold for $500, only for him suddenly brought you in a whole lot of money, who would you think it belonged to?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: I didn't realize bow much he meant to you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Hello Governor!
( seeing KELLOGG)
Oh, here you are — Where's your luggage?

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: My man has it at the hotel.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p: I'll go after it.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh no — but you might telephone and tell them to show Mr. Kellogg's man the way over here.

sp.speaker: GRAHAM.
sp.p:
Yes, I will,
( exits into house )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Thanks.
( turns to HARRY and looks at him steadily )
Well I'm not going through with this thing.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
No?
( crossing to C.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.stage: ( getting check and note from his pocket )
sp.p: No — Here's a check for four hundred — all the money I've got now — and a note for the balance.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Oh Nat, I don't want these.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You'll take them just the same — I'd rather pay that back than be president.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: Well, we'll talk this over later. First, what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: The only thing left to do. See Lockwood and his daughter and tell him the whole thing.

sp.speaker: KELLOGG.
sp.p: You've got a pleasant little job ahead of you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I don't care about that. It's Josie I'm thinking of. Why it's awful Harry to trick a girl into caring for you and then to — to —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
To break her heart? Don't flatter yourself. It isn't that she loves you — it's because you're the best chance she's seen. My system would have
worked just as well if anyone else had tried it.
( going down R.)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( coming up and sitting on upper end of steps R.)
sp.p: I'm sure of it — The trouble is that people know you're engaged and they'll say you've thrown her over and that's going to make her feel pretty cheap for a while, but she'll get over it, only you'll lose a fortune, don't forget that.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, I won't — I never had it and I don't want it.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, I hope you'll always feel that way about it but you'll find money a great help if you want to live a happy life.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: There are better things than money to make a man happy.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You got that from a book.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No I didn't — I found it out.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I had everything when I was in college — youth, health and all the money I wanted and lots of friends and I thought I was a pretty lucky and a pretty happy kid but I know how you can beat that sort of happiness to death. Harry, the real way to be happy is to work and have your work amount to something and to have someone who believes in you to work for.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Oh you're learning how to preach.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Call it what you like but it goes just the same. I've found that out this year.
( goes L. C.)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.stage: ( getting up and going to NAT C.)
sp.p: And you're right. I'm glad you backed out, it was a low down scheme and I proposed it — well, I suppose, because I'm a schemer and I knew it would work — but it's made a man of you Nat and I'm mighty glad.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: What has changed you all of a sudden?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I've talked with Graham and I've seen his daughter.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
And now if you don't mind I'd like to see her again.
( goes R. on to porch )

div.stage: (ROLAND, LOCKWOOD, JOSIE and PETE enter L.) ( Dim out borders .)

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Here he is.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: So, we've found you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I didn't know I was lost.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: I want a word with you young man.

div.stage: (JOSIE R. C. ROLAND L. PETE R. at porch .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Well, sir?

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: There ain't no use beatin' around the bush. You've behaved yourself since you been in this town, but nobody knows who you are or what you were before you came here, and now Roland's made a charge again you.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I accused him of it to-night and he didn't deny it.

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: And he says he can prove it?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Prove what?

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: That you're a thief with a reward out for you. You're James Hilton that ran away from the N. Y. National Bank.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Why you —

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Hold on — you got my daughter to say she'd marry you to-night, and I want to know more about this bank business before it goes any further.

div.stage: (NAT stops suddenly. Looks at LOCKWOOD a moment and then at JOSIE — then front showing he's decided to take this way out .)

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
Do you deny it?
( pause )
Answer!

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I refuse to answer.

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: Ah — ha! What did I tell you?

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Don't ask me.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Is it true?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: You heard what he said.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Oh — I — I despise you.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: That's all right — I've despised myself all the evening.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: Papa!

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p: Don't give me the credit — thank Roland — he got on to him.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: I do thank you Roland and I can never be grateful enough. Won't you take me away from this place?

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I'll be mighty glad to see you home if you'll let me.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p:
I'd like to have you very much — oh, Roland, how foolish I've been — I believe I've liked you beet all along.
( they go R.)

sp.speaker: ROLAND.
sp.p: I never saw anybody from New York yet that wasn't a crook.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.stage: ( they turn up stage and she catches NAT'S eye and stops )
sp.p: How did you dare pretend to care for me?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: It was one of the rules.

sp.speaker: JOSIE.
sp.p: There is no need to say I suppose that the engagement is broken.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Come along to jail Mr. Duncan — Much better.

div.stage: (JOSIE and ROLAND exit L.)

sp.speaker: LOCKWOOD.
sp.p:
You look after him — I'll attend to his case in the morning. I'll make you wish you'd never come to this town.
( exits L.)

div.stage: ( Dim out foots .)

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Say look here —

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: You've been saved just in time, Mr. Duncan — My, my, my, you're a lucky man. Now you better make tracks — I ain't got no warrant to hold you — and I wouldn't if I had.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: I'm not the fellow they think I am and it's easy enough to prove it.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Git out just the same or you may have to marry her after all.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: No, I won't.

sp.speaker: PETE.
sp.p: Thank God for that — I feel so good about this, I'm goin' home and give my wife hell!

div.stage: (NAT and KELLOGG laugh . KELLOGG comes down off porch .)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well that was a bit of luck.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
A bit of luck! It's more luck than I thought there was in the whole world.
( goes L.)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Here, where are you going?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Over to have it out with Lockwood.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You better leave Lockwood to me.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: All right — tell him —

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I know what to tell him.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Thanks Harry.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p:
Supper is ready and —
( seeing NAT is there alone she stops suddenly, embarrassed )

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
Betty — I want to tell you something.
( she comes down to him )
Do you happen to remember that I told you awhile ago I was engaged to Josie Lockwood —

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Nothing much only it's broken off.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Broken off! Why?

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p: Because I love you.

sp.speaker: BETTY.
sp.p: Oh, Nat, I don't understand.

sp.speaker: NAT.
sp.p:
It was a plan, a scheme, my coming here, everything I did, a disgraceful, contemptible trick,
( rain )
but it's different now. I love you, Betty and I want to be a man. Won't you forgive me and be my wife?

div.stage: ( During this speech rain starts — as rain starts GRAHAM comes into door of house and sees them and they are all unconscious of the rain — GRAHAM goes in and gets umbrella and holds it over them .)
